events.title: CT Head, No Contrast
events.notes: At 14:46, the claimant underwent a non-contrast CT head at KFH Hayward Radiology - CTS due to symptoms suggestive of stroke or transient ischemic attack (TIA). The imaging was performed using 2.5 mm contiguous axial slices through the head without intravenous contrast, with coronal reformatted images generated. Findings revealed normal ventricular and sulcal sizes, preserved gray-white differentiation, and no evidence of acute intracranial hemorrhage, abnormal extra-axial fluid collection, or mass effect. The calvarium, scalp, orbits, paranasal sinuses, and mastoid air cells were unremarkable. Impression confirmed no acute intracranial bleed or other abnormalities. Results were finalized at 16:34.
events.description_full: The patient presented with symptoms suggestive of stroke or transient ischemic attack (TIA). A non-contrast CT head was ordered STAT at 14:46 by Dr. Park, David Kyung-Il. The imaging was performed using 2.5 mm contiguous axial slices through the head without intravenous contrast administration, with coronal reformatted images generated. The estimated radiation dose was CTDIvol 56.12 mGy and DLP 1013.96 mGy-cm. Findings included normal ventricular and sulcal sizes, no evidence of acute intracranial hemorrhage, abnormal extra-axial fluid collection, or mass effect. Gray-white differentiation was preserved, with no signs of large vascular territory infarct. The calvarium and soft tissues of the scalp were unremarkable, and visualized portions of the orbits, globes, paranasal sinuses, and mastoid air cells were normal. The impression concluded no acute intracranial bleed or other abnormalities. The final result was filed at 16:34, confirming no acute findings. The imaging was performed at KFH Hayward Radiology - CTS and dictated by Dr. Rajshri Nayakwadi Shah.

events.title: Patient Education on CA-UTIs
events.notes: The claimant reviewed a patient education document regarding catheter-associated urinary tract infections (CA-UTIs). The document outlined symptoms, including abdominal pain, fever, and bloody urine, and emphasized the importance of proper catheter care and hygiene to prevent infections. Treatment options, such as antibiotics and catheter replacement, were discussed. Preventative measures and guidance for at-home catheter care were also provided, along with instructions to seek medical attention if symptoms develop.
events.description_full: The patient education document reviewed on 2016-03-02 provides detailed information about catheter-associated urinary tract infections (CA-UTIs). It explains that individuals with urinary catheters are at a significantly higher risk of developing urinary tract infections compared to those without catheters. The document outlines the symptoms of CA-UTIs, which may include burning or pain in the lower abdomen, fever, bloody urine, burning during urination, or increased frequency of urination after catheter removal. It also notes that some individuals may not exhibit these symptoms. The document emphasizes that CA-UTIs are treatable with antibiotics and removal or replacement of the catheter, with the choice of antibiotic determined by the healthcare provider. Preventative measures are described, including proper hand hygiene by healthcare providers, sterile catheter insertion techniques, cleaning the skin before insertion, securing the catheter to prevent pulling, avoiding twisting or kinking of the tubing, and keeping the urine bag below the bladder level to prevent backflow. Patients are advised to clean their hands before and after catheter care, avoid tugging or pulling on the tubing, and inquire daily about the necessity of the catheter. The document also provides guidance for patients going home with a catheter, stressing the importance of understanding catheter care and knowing whom to contact in case of questions or problems. It advises patients to seek medical attention if symptoms of a urinary tract infection develop. The document is co-sponsored by several reputable organizations, including the Society for Healthcare Epidemiology of America, Infectious Diseases Society of America, American Hospital Association, Association for Professionals in Infection Control and Epidemiology, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, and The Joint Commission.

events.title: Patient Education on Catheter-Associated UTIs
events.notes: The claimant received a patient education document detailing catheter-associated urinary tract infections (CA-UTIs). The document explained causes, symptoms, prevention, and treatment of CA-UTIs, emphasizing that infections often occur during catheter use. Symptoms include abdominal pain, fever, and burning during urination, though some individuals may be asymptomatic. Treatment involves antibiotics and catheter removal or replacement. Preventative measures include proper hand hygiene, timely catheter removal, and daily assessment of catheter necessity. Instructions for home care were provided, including recognizing infection symptoms and contacting healthcare providers with concerns. The document was co-sponsored by reputable organizations such as SHEA, IDSA, APIC, CDC, and The Joint Commission.
events.description_full: The document provides detailed information about catheter-associated urinary tract infections (CA-UTIs), including their causes, symptoms, prevention, and treatment. It explains that CA-UTIs occur when germs enter the urinary tract, often during catheter insertion or while the catheter remains in the bladder. Common symptoms include burning or pain in the lower abdomen, fever, bloody urine, and burning during urination, though some individuals may not exhibit symptoms. The document emphasizes that CA-UTIs can be treated with antibiotics and removal or replacement of the catheter, with the choice of antibiotic determined by the healthcare provider. Preventative measures outlined include using catheters only when necessary, removing them as soon as possible, ensuring proper hand hygiene by healthcare providers, cleaning the skin before catheter insertion, and securing the catheter to prevent pulling or kinking. Patients are advised to clean their hands before and after catheter care, keep the urine bag below bladder level, avoid tugging or twisting the tubing, and ask their healthcare provider daily if the catheter is still needed. The document also provides instructions for patients going home with a catheter, including understanding catheter care, recognizing symptoms of infection, and knowing whom to contact for questions or problems. It highlights the importance of discussing any concerns with healthcare providers and notes that the information is co-sponsored by several reputable organizations, including SHEA, IDSA, APIC, CDC, and The Joint Commission.

events.title: Clinical Notes
events.notes: The patient was assessed for ongoing management of acute CVA and associated complications. Active problems included hypertensive emergency and type 2 diabetes mellitus in the context of obesity. Following a right decompressive hemicraniectomy and ICP monitor placement, imaging confirmed a 1.5 cm right-to-left subfalcine herniation with compression of bilateral ventricles. MRI findings from February 26 showed a large right MCA infarction with hemosiderin deposition, petechial staining, and a 1.2 cm leftward midline shift. The patient remained intubated and sedated, with bradycardia, coarse crackles, and absent gag reflex noted on examination. Glasgow Coma Scale score was 14. Ongoing monitoring and management of cerebral edema and herniation were planned.
events.description_full: The patient was assessed for ongoing management of acute CVA and associated complications. The principal problem was identified as CVA (cerebral vascular accident). Active problems included hypertensive emergency and type 2 diabetes mellitus in the context of obesity. The patient had a right uncal herniation with brainstem compression following a right decompressive hemicraniectomy and placement of a subdural ICP monitor on February 27, 2023, by Dr. Suh. There was also a right-to-left subfalcine herniation measuring 1.5 cm with compression of bilateral ventricles. The acute CVA was associated with a right M1 occlusion, edema, midline shift, and herniation. The patient had previously received TNK administration on February 17, 2023, at an outside hospital and underwent a partially successful aspiration and mechanical thrombectomy of the right MCA. Imaging findings from February 21, 2023, and February 23, 2023, were reviewed, showing stable infarct appearance and mass effect. The MRI from February 26, 2023, confirmed evolving infarction with hemosiderin deposition and a 1.2 cm leftward midline shift. The patient remained sedated and on mechanical ventilation, with weak cough and spontaneous movement of the right upper extremity reported by nursing staff. Babinski reflex was mute bilaterally, and corneal reflexes were present. The assessment included ongoing monitoring and management of cerebral edema, herniation, and associated complications.

events.title: MRI Brain
events.notes: At 01:00, the patient underwent an MRI of the brain without intravenous contrast as part of the initial stroke workup, which had been delayed due to clinical status. Findings revealed an evolving large right MCA territory subacute infarction with petechial staining and hemosiderin deposition, causing a 1.2 cm leftward midline shift, increased from 5 mm noted on the February 24 CT scan. A punctate cortical infarct was also identified in the left frontal lobe posteriorly. Mass effect and effacement of the right lateral ventricle were observed. The imaging was reviewed and electronically signed by Dr. Andreas Schilling at 02:16. No changes to the treatment plan were documented.
events.description_full: The patient underwent an MRI BATT at approximately 01:00 as part of the initial stroke workup, which had been delayed due to the patient's clinical status. The imaging revealed an evolving large right MCA territory subacute infarction with scattered regions of petechial staining and hemosiderin deposition. There was a resultant 1.2 cm leftward midline shift, which was a significant increase compared to the 5 mm shift noted on the CT scan from February 24, 2020. Additionally, a punctate cortical infarct was identified in the left frontal lobe posteriorly. No abnormal brain parenchymal signal intensity, significant volume loss, mass, or extra-axial fluid collection was observed. Mass effect and effacement of the right lateral ventricle were noted. Despite these findings, there was no documentation of a change in the patient's mental status or any adjustment to the treatment plan based on the imaging results. The attending radiologist reviewed all images, agreed with the interpretation, and provided appropriate supervision for the exam.

events.title: Laboratory Results
events.notes: At 01:04, laboratory results revealed mild anemia with hemoglobin at 11.8 g/dL and hematocrit at 36.5%. Platelet count was normal at 249 x10^3/uL. Electrolytes showed mild hypernatremia (147.07 mmol/L), hyperchloremia (110.08 mmol/L), and elevated CO2 (35 mmol/L). BUN was elevated at 30 mg/dL, while creatinine remained normal at 0.97 mg/dL. Glucose was elevated at 166.50 mg/dL. Liver function tests showed elevated AST (58 U/L) and alkaline phosphatase (136.19 U/L). Magnesium and phosphorus levels were slightly decreased compared to prior results. These findings were consistent with metabolic derangements secondary to the patient's critical illness.
events.description_full: Laboratory results from 01:04 included a CBC and BMP. Hemoglobin was 11.8 g/dL (slightly decreased from 12.2 g/dL on 02/25), hematocrit was 36.5% (down from 37.3% on 02/25), and platelets were 249 x10^3/uL (stable). Sodium was 147.07 mmol/L (mildly elevated), potassium was 3.6 mmol/L (normal), chloride was 110.08 mmol/L (mildly elevated), CO2 was 35 mmol/L (elevated), BUN was 30 mg/dL (elevated), creatinine was 0.97 mg/dL (normal), and glucose was 166.50 mg/dL (elevated). Magnesium was 2.4 mg/dL (slightly decreased from 2.5 mg/dL on 02/25), and phosphorus was 3.36 mg/dL (decreased from 4.47 mg/dL on 02/25). Liver function tests showed total protein at 6.1 g/dL, bilirubin at 0.4 mg/dL, ALT at 41 U/L, AST at 58 U/L (elevated), and alkaline phosphatase at 136.19 U/L (elevated). These results were consistent with ongoing metabolic derangements and mild liver enzyme elevation, likely secondary to the patient's critical illness.

events.provider: Neurological team at Savannah Memorial Hospital
events.title: Thrombectomy and Post-Procedure Care
events.notes: The patient, Frank Ward, suffered a stroke and underwent a thrombectomy performed by the neurological team at Memorial Health University Medical Center. Post-procedure, he was admitted to the ICU, where his condition initially stabilized with noted improvements in motor, cognitive, and verbal functions. However, documentation indicates a subsequent decline in these functions, which was not addressed appropriately at the time. The patient was later transferred to the main floor for continued monitoring, with concerns for potential brain swelling noted but not acted upon.
events.description_full: The patient, Frank Ward, suffered a stroke and underwent a thrombectomy performed by the neurological team at Memorial Health University Medical Center. Following the procedure, the patient was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU). His condition stabilized, and improvements were noted in his motor, cognitive, and verbal functions. The patient was subsequently discharged from the ICU to the main floor of the hospital for continued monitoring. The medical team was expected to frequently monitor the patient for signs of neurological decline, particularly brain swelling, which is a known risk factor following a stroke. However, documentation indicates that despite multiple providers noting a decline in the patient’s verbal, cognitive, and motor functions, no appropriate action was taken at that time.

events.title: MRI Brain
events.notes: Following a noted decline in verbal, cognitive, and motor functions, an MRI of the brain was performed. The imaging revealed a recent and evolving brain bleed, which was identified as the cause of the patient’s neurological deterioration. events.description_full: After the patient began to exhibit a decline in verbal, cognitive, and motor functions, an MRI of the brain was performed. The MRI revealed a recent and evolving brain bleed, which was identified as the cause of the patient’s neurological decline. The findings required immediate medical attention. However, despite the critical nature of the results, no action was taken by the hospital staff at that time. This delay in care is noted as a significant deviation from the standard of care.

events.title: CT Head
events.notes: Over 30 hours after the MRI, a CT scan of the head was performed. The imaging confirmed the presence of a brain bleed and revealed compression of the brainstem due to swelling. These findings were consistent with the patient’s ongoing neurological decline. The delay in performing the CT scan and addressing its findings is noted as a critical lapse in care, contributing to severe brain damage.
events.description_full: More than 30 hours after the MRI was performed, a CT scan of the patient’s head was conducted. The CT scan confirmed the presence of a brain bleed and showed compression of the brainstem due to brain swelling. These findings were consistent with the patient’s ongoing neurological decline. The delay in performing the CT scan and addressing the findings is noted as a critical lapse in care, contributing to the patient’s severe brain damage.

events.title: Stroke Education Document
events.notes: The patient received an educational document on stroke management and prevention at Renown Regional Medical Center. The document outlined stroke risk factors, symptoms, and treatment options, emphasizing the importance of timely medical intervention within 3-6 hours of symptom onset. Preventative measures such as managing blood pressure, cholesterol, and diabetes, as well as lifestyle modifications, were detailed. The document also included the 'BE FAST' mnemonic for recognizing stroke symptoms and provided recommendations from the American Heart Association on diet and exercise.
events.description_full: The document provides detailed patient education regarding stroke, including risk factors, symptoms, treatment, and prevention strategies. Risk factors are categorized into modifiable (e.g., smoking, birth control use, physical inactivity) and non-modifiable (e.g., age over 60, prior stroke or TIA, family history). Symptoms of stroke are described as sudden onset weakness or loss of sensation in the face, arm, or leg (often unilateral), loss of balance, slurred speech, difficulty understanding speech, visual disturbances, dizziness, nausea, vomiting, and severe headache. The document emphasizes the importance of noting the exact time of symptom onset and seeking immediate medical attention, as treatments are most effective within 3-6 hours of symptom onset. Treatment options include clot-dissolving medications, blood pressure control, blood thinners, oxygen therapy, IV fluids, and procedures to restore blood flow. Post-stroke rehabilitation with therapists is also mentioned. Home care instructions include taking medications as prescribed, dietary modifications, safety measures to prevent falls, and avoiding smoking or excessive alcohol consumption. Preventative measures for reducing stroke risk include managing high blood pressure, cholesterol, diabetes, heart disease, and sleep problems, as well as maintaining a healthy weight, diet, and exercise routine. The document also outlines the 'BE FAST' mnemonic for recognizing stroke symptoms: Balance issues, Eye changes, Facial droop, Arm weakness, Speech difficulties, and Time to call emergency services. The document concludes with general lifestyle recommendations from the American Heart Association, including the DASH and Mediterranean diets and regular exercise. The document was revised and reviewed on 07/28/2021.

events.notes: On February 17, 2023, the claimant underwent a CT scan of the head and a CT angiogram at St. Joseph's Candler Hospital after presenting with symptoms of a stroke. events.description_full: On February 17, 2023, the claimant suffered a stroke and was brought to St. Joseph's Candler Hospital. A CT scan of the head and a CT angiogram were performed, which revealed a right M1 occlusion. These imaging studies confirmed the presence of a blockage in the right middle cerebral artery, a critical finding consistent with an acute ischemic stroke. The results necessitated immediate medical intervention.

events.title: Thrombolytic and Blood Pressure Medications Administered
events.notes: Following the imaging results on February 17, 2023, the claimant was administered labetalol, started on a Cardene drip, and given Tenecteplase. Labetalol and Cardene were used to manage blood pressure, while Tenecteplase, a thrombolytic agent, was administered to dissolve the clot in the right middle cerebral artery. Dosages and times of administration were not documented.
events.description_full: Following the imaging results, the claimant was administered labetalol, started on a Cardene drip, and given Tenecteplase. Labetalol was likely used to manage blood pressure, while Cardene (nicardipine) was used for continuous blood pressure control. Tenecteplase, a thrombolytic agent, was administered to dissolve the clot in the right middle cerebral artery. The exact dosages and times of administration were not documented in the provided text.

events.title: Thrombectomy
events.notes: Upon arrival at Savannah Memorial Hospital on February 17, 2023, the claimant underwent an urgent thrombectomy of the right middle cerebral artery. The procedure successfully removed the clot in the right M1 segment, restoring blood flow. Post-procedure, the claimant experienced improved perfusion with no reported complications.
events.description_full: Upon arrival at Savannah Memorial Hospital, the claimant underwent an urgent thrombectomy of the right middle cerebral artery. This procedure aimed to mechanically remove the clot causing the occlusion in the right M1 segment. Post-procedure, the claimant reportedly experienced improved blood flow, indicating successful revascularization. No complications or adverse events were noted in the provided text.

The result was authorized by Dr. Igor Aksenov and processed by Memorial Health Laboratory, Savannah, GA. The Hemoglobin A1C level was reported as 10.3%, significantly above the reference range of 4.0-5.6%. The narrative accompanying the result explained that values between 5.7-6.4% indicate an increased risk for developing diabetes mellitus, while values greater than or equal to 6.5% are diagnostic of diabetes mellitus. For individuals without unequivocal hyperglycemia, repeat testing is recommended to confirm the diagnosis. The specimen used for testing was whole blood. This result strongly suggests that the claimant has diabetes mellitus, requiring further clinical management and monitoring.

events.title: Upper GI Endoscopy and PEG Tube Placement
events.notes: The claimant underwent an upper GI endoscopy and PEG tube placement due to dysphagia. The procedure was performed under sedation, with the stomach accessed percutaneously under direct visualization. A PEG tube was placed and secured at 5 cm depth, connected to gravity drainage. The patient tolerated the procedure well, with no complications noted. Post-procedure, the patient was stable in the PACU, with the PEG tube set to gravity drainage for 24 hours and cleared for medication administration.
events.description_full: The patient, Frank Ward, underwent an upper GI endoscopy and PEG tube placement on 02/17/2023 at Memorial Health. The procedure was indicated due to dysphagia. Prior to sedation, red rules procedures and time-out policies were followed. The patient was adequately sedated and placed in the supine position with a protective bite block between the teeth. The endoscope was advanced through the upper esophageal sphincter into the stomach without difficulty. The stomach was fully visualized, retroflexed to examine the gastroesophageal junction, and the pylorus was identified. The endoscope was passed into the duodenum, visualizing the first and second portions. The anterior abdominal wall was palpated and transillumination was used to select the best site for PEG tube placement. The area was prepared and draped in sterile fashion. Local anesthesia with 1% lidocaine and epinephrine was administered. A 1 cm incision was made, and the stomach was accessed percutaneously under direct visualization. A catheter was placed, and the PEG tube was fastened to the pull wire, drawn through the esophagus, and brought through the abdominal wall. The tube was secured at 5 cm depth, cut to length, and connected to gravity drainage. The patient tolerated the procedure well, with no complications noted. The attending physician was present throughout the critical portions of the procedure. Post-procedure, the patient was stable in the PACU, with the PEG tube set to gravity drainage for 24 hours and cleared for medication administration.

events.title: Stroke Evaluation - Last Known Well Time
events.notes: At 06:15, the claimant, a 53-year-old male, collapsed at a gas station, marking the last known well time. Upon presentation, he exhibited left-sided weakness, slurred speech, and facial droop. Initial vitals included BP 206/110 mmHg, HR 72 bpm, RR 16 bpm, and glucose 253 mg/dL. NIH Stroke Scale scored 10, revealing partial paralysis, sensory loss, and no aphasia. CT imaging at 06:59 showed no acute findings, while CTA revealed severe right MCA stenosis/occlusion. CTP demonstrated salvageable brain tissue. Recommendations included tPA administration after BP control and mechanical thrombectomy at a local MT center.
events.description_full: The patient, a 53-year-old male, collapsed at a gas station at approximately 06:15. This was identified as the last known well time. Upon presentation, the patient exhibited left arm and leg weakness, slurred speech, and left-sided facial droop. The patient was noted to have a history of diabetes. Initial vitals included blood pressure of 206/110 mmHg, heart rate of 72 bpm, respiratory rate of 16 bpm, and point-of-care glucose of 253 mg/dL. The patient weighed 136 kg. NIH Stroke Scale was completed, scoring 10, with findings of partial paralysis of the lower face, no effort against gravity in the left arm, no movement in the left leg, mild-to-moderate sensory loss, and no aphasia or dysarthria. CT imaging was ordered at 06:59 and completed shortly thereafter, showing no acute findings. CTA revealed severe right M1 segment stenosis/occlusion, and CTP demonstrated a penumbra volume of 212 mL with no core infarct. The patient was deemed a good candidate for tPA administration once blood pressure was reduced below 185/110 mmHg. Mechanical thrombectomy was also indicated, and transfer to a local MT center was recommended. Recommendations included stroke education, avoidance of Foley catheter, and use of pneumatic compression devices. Diagnostic workup included MRI head, MRA head, and transthoracic echocardiogram.

events.title: ED to Hospital Admission
events.notes: At 08:45, the patient arrived at the emergency department via ambulance with a chief complaint of extremity weakness. Admission was completed at 08:58, and the patient was transferred to the Neuro ICU. Diagnoses included acute ischemic stroke, hypertensive emergency, and impaired mobility. Additional issues included anemia, acute kidney injury, respiratory insufficiency, and pneumonia. The patient was admitted in serious condition and treated in critical care. The attending provider was Dr. Allan M. Taaca. Discharge was planned for inpatient rehabilitation on 05/03/2023.
events.description_full: The patient arrived at the emergency department via ambulance at 08:45 with a chief complaint of extremity weakness. Admission was completed at 08:58, and the patient was transferred to the SAV 2 HV NEURO ICU. The primary diagnosis was acute ischemic stroke, with additional diagnoses including weakness of one side of the body, hypertensive emergency, impaired mobility, and status post head surgery. The patient also had a documented presence of an inferior vena cava filter. Hospital problems included anemia due to acute blood loss, acute kidney injury, respiratory insufficiency, heart arrest, type 2 diabetes mellitus with obesity, difficulty swallowing, persistent proteinuria, pneumonia of the right lower lobe due to Pseudomonas species, pneumonia due to Staphylococcus, and structural encephalopathy. The admitting provider was Dr. Igor Aksenov, and the attending provider was Dr. Allan M. Taaca. The patient was admitted in serious condition and treated in critical care. The admission type was emergency, and the point of origin was non-healthcare facility. The patient was discharged on 05/03/2023 to inpatient rehab with a plan for readmission.

events.notes: At 09:11, a blood sample was collected for a CBC with auto differential. Results showed WBC 8.0 K/uL, RBC 5.06 M/uL, Hemoglobin 15.1 g/dL, and Hematocrit 43.4%. Neutrophils were elevated at 78.7%. No complications were noted during collection or processing.
events.description_full: On 02/17/2023 at 09:11, a blood sample was collected by Geoffrey Beecher, RN, for a complete blood count (CBC) with auto differential at Memorial Health. The test was ordered by Dr. Allan M. Taaca at 08:56. The specimen was processed by Memorial Health Laboratory, and the final result was reported at 09:21. The results showed the following values: WBC 8.0 K/uL (normal range: 4.5-11.0), RBC 5.06 M/uL (normal range: 4.50-5.90), Hemoglobin 15.1 g/dL (normal range: 13.5-17.5), Hematocrit 43.4% (normal range: 41.0-53.0), MCV 85.8 fL (normal range: 80.0-95.0), MCH 29.8 pq (normal range: 25.0-35.0), MCHC 34.8 g/dL (normal range: 30.0-36.0), RDW 11.9% (normal range: 11.5-14.6), MPV 11.5 fL (no established reference range), Neutrophils 78.7% (elevated, normal range: 40.0-70.0), Lymphocytes 15.1% (normal range: 15.0-45.0), Monocytes 5.1% (normal range: 1.0-8.0), Eosinophils 0.7% (normal range: 0.0-6.0), Basophils 0.4% (normal range: 0.0-2.0), Platelets 256 K/uL (normal range: 150-450). The elevated neutrophil percentage was flagged as abnormal. No complications or issues were noted during the collection or processing of the specimen.

events.title: Admission to Neuro ICU
events.notes: At 09:27, the claimant was admitted to the Neuro ICU at Memorial University Medical Center following evaluation in the emergency department. The claimant was diagnosed with a right middle cerebral artery cerebrovascular accident (CVA) with evolution. Clinical documentation noted prior craniectomy, dense left hemiparesis, and advanced airway and nutritional support. The claimant's care plan included ongoing monitoring and tailored precautions.
events.description_full: At 09:27 on 2023-02-17, the claimant was admitted to the Neuro ICU at Memorial University Medical Center following evaluation in the emergency department. The claimant was noted to have a right middle cerebral artery (MCA) cerebrovascular accident (CVA) with evolution. The clinical documentation indicates the claimant had undergone a craniectomy and was using a helmet when up. The claimant also had a capped tracheostomy and a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube in place. The claimant was described as having dense left hemiparesis with upper extremity subluxation. The documentation does not provide specific details regarding the claimant’s initial presentation, vital signs, or neurological examination findings at the time of admission. However, the presence of significant neurological deficits and the need for advanced airway and nutritional support suggest a severe and evolving stroke. The claimant’s care plan included ongoing monitoring in the Neuro ICU, with precautions and equipment tailored to their condition. The record does not specify the provider responsible for the admission or the immediate management plan.

events.title: CBC and Comprehensive Metabolic Panel
events.notes: At 00:38, a complete blood count with differential and a comprehensive metabolic panel were collected. CBC results showed leukocytosis with elevated WBC at 17.3 K/uL, mild anemia with decreased RBC at 4.35 M/uL, hemoglobin at 13.1 g/dL, and hematocrit at 38.4%. Neutrophils were elevated at 86.7%, and lymphocytes were decreased at 5.6%, suggesting possible bacterial infection. CMP results revealed elevated glucose at 229.04 mg/dL, chloride at 110.42 mmol/L, and BUN at 28 mg/dL, alongside decreased calcium at 8.2 mg/dL, albumin at 2.9 g/dL, and phosphorus at 2.48 mg/dL. These findings indicated potential metabolic derangements, but no follow-up actions were documented.
events.description_full: A complete blood count with differential was collected at 00:38. Results showed elevated white blood cell count (WBC) at 17.3 K/uL (reference range: 4.5-11.0 K/uL), indicating leukocytosis, which may suggest infection or inflammation. Red blood cell count (RBC) was low at 4.35 M/uL (reference range: 4.50-5.90 M/uL), hemoglobin was slightly decreased at 13.1 g/dL (reference range: 13.5-17.5 g/dL), and hematocrit was reduced at 38.4% (reference range: 41.0-53.0%), suggesting mild anemia. Neutrophils were elevated at 86.7% (reference range: 40.0-70.0%), while lymphocytes were decreased at 5.6% (reference range: 15.0-45.0%), consistent with a possible bacterial infection. Platelet count was within normal limits at 246 K/uL. No additional clinical interpretation or follow-up actions were documented. A comprehensive metabolic panel was collected at 00:38. Results included elevated glucose at 229.04 mg/dL (reference range: 74-106 mg/dL), elevated chloride at 110.42 mmol/L (reference range: 98-107 mmol/L), and elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN) at 28 mg/dL (reference range: 9-21 mg/dL). Calcium was low at 8.2 mg/dL (reference range: 8.5-10.5 mg/dL), albumin was decreased at 2.9 g/dL (reference range: 3.0-5.0 g/dL), and the albumin/globulin ratio was less than 1.1 (reference range: >=1.1). The anion gap was reduced at 6 (reference range: 10-20), and phosphorus was slightly low at 2.48 mg/dL (reference range: 2.5-4.5 mg/dL). These findings suggest potential metabolic derangements, including possible dehydration, renal dysfunction, or nutritional deficiencies. No specific clinical actions or follow-up were documented in response to these findings.

events.title: CT Head Without Contrast
events.notes: At 05:31, the claimant underwent a CT scan of the head without IV contrast to evaluate for acute stroke. Findings included a dense right MCA sign and a large region of hypoattenuation within the right MCA distribution, consistent with acute infarction. Stable edema and mass effect were noted with partial effacement of the right lateral ventricle. No parenchymal hematoma or hemorrhagic transformation was identified. The impression indicated continued evolution of the right MCA infarct with no significant change compared to prior imaging.
events.description_full: A CT scan of the head without IV contrast was performed to evaluate for acute stroke. Sagittal and coronal reformats were obtained. The findings included a dense right MCA sign and a large region of hypoattenuation within the right MCA distribution with loss of gray-white matter differentiation, consistent with acute infarction. Stable edema and mass effect were noted with partial effacement of the right lateral ventricle. No significant parenchymal hematoma was identified. The basal cisterns were patent, and the density of the dural venous sinuses was normal. The skull base and calvarium were normal. The paranasal sinuses and mastoid air cells were predominantly clear, and the visualized orbits were unremarkable. The impression indicated continued evolution of the right MCA infarct with no appreciable hemorrhagic transformation and no significant change compared to the prior study. The findings were interpreted and electronically signed by Dr. Jason Snyder at 05:31.

events.title: EMS Narrative Report
events.notes: On February 21, EMS transported Frank Ward to Memorial Health University Medical Center following a large vessel occlusion (LVO) stroke. He presented with left-sided facial droop and weakness but was alert and oriented (GCS 15). Vitals were stable: BP 146/90, pulse 96, RR 18, O2 saturation 98%. TNK was administered at 07:52, and he was on a Cardene drip. During transport, he remained stable. Upon arrival, a stroke assessment was performed, and he was admitted to the neuro ICU. His history included hypertension and non-insulin-dependent diabetes.
events.description_full: The EMS narrative report detailed the transport of the patient, Frank Ward, who was identified as having a large vessel occlusion (LVO) stroke. EMS responded to the scene where the patient was found in a semi-fowler's position on the bed, displaying left-sided facial droop and left-sided weakness. The patient was alert and oriented (GCS 15) with stable vitals: blood pressure 146/90, pulse 96, respiratory rate 18, and oxygen saturation 98%. The patient was on a Cardene drip for elevated blood pressure, and an 18-gauge IV was established in the right antecubital vein by St. Joe. TNK (Tenecteplase) was administered at 07:52 AM. The patient was transferred to a stretcher using a draw sheet method and attached to a cardiac monitor, which showed sinus rhythm without ectopic beats. During transport, the patient was continuously monitored, and no changes in condition were noted. Upon arrival at Memorial Health University Medical Center, the patient underwent a stroke assessment, which caused a delay. The patient was then transferred to the neuro ICU (B-15) and care was handed over to the nurse on duty. The EMS team documented the patient's medical history, including primary hypertension and non-insulin-dependent diabetes, and noted no recent travel or exposure to illness. The report provides detailed information about the patient's prehospital care and transport, including the administration of TNK and the patient's stable condition throughout.

events.title: Occupational Therapy Progress Note
events.notes: At 13:02, the patient was evaluated by occupational therapy. He was alert and conversant but required cues for attention and task initiation. Left-sided neglect and decreased safety awareness were noted. Bed mobility required maximum assistance, and sitting balance training was conducted for 10 minutes. Improvements in left-side awareness were observed despite persistent neglect. ADLs included self-feeding with minimal assistance. Recommendations included intensive neuro-based therapy post-discharge, focusing on balance, ADL training, and neuromuscular re-education.
events.description_full: The patient was evaluated by occupational therapy. Subjectively, the patient was noted to be more alert and conversant, with his wife present at the bedside. Precautions included fall risk, supplemental oxygen, and monitoring for right MCA CVA evolution post-TNK and thrombectomy on 2/17. Pain assessment revealed no reports of pain. Objective evaluation showed the patient was alert, oriented to person, place, and situation, but required cues to redirect attention and initiate tasks. Safety judgment and awareness of errors were decreased. Perception findings included neglect of the left side of the body and visual field, requiring verbal cues to maintain midline. Bed mobility required maximum assistance from two individuals, and sitting balance training was conducted at the edge of the bed for approximately 10 minutes before fatigue set in. The patient demonstrated a left lean with decreased midline awareness and head control, with a right gaze preference. Improvement was noted in attending to the left side of the environment, though neglect persisted despite maximum verbal cues. Left upper extremity was positioned for weight-bearing to promote midline control and neuromuscular input. Activities of daily living included self-feeding with minimal assistance and contact guard assistance to place a spoon in the mouth. The patient was left in bed with call light and essentials within reach, and a right restraint was in place. Assessment indicated progress as expected, with continuation of the occupational therapy plan of care. Recommendations included intensive neuro-based therapy post-discharge, with interventions focusing on balance, ADL/IADL training, functional mobility, therapeutic exercises, neuromuscular re-education, and patient/family education. Electronically signed by Claire Graupmann, OT at 13:09.

events.title: Occupational Therapy Progress Note
events.notes: At 12:46, the claimant underwent an occupational therapy session with Claire Graupmann, OT, at Memorial Health. The patient was noted to be food motivated and reported no pain. Cognitive evaluation revealed mild impairments, requiring repetition and cues for one-step commands. Perceptual assessment showed inattention and neglect, requiring cues to maintain midline and attend to the left side. Sitting balance was assessed, with the patient sitting at the edge of the bed for 10 minutes before fatigue. Improved head control was noted with assistance. ADLs included self-feeding with standby assistance. The assessment indicated progress, with recommendations for continued therapy focusing on balance, ADLs, functional mobility, and neuro-based rehabilitation.
events.description_full: The patient agreed to treatment and was noted to be food motivated, asking for the 'ice lady' (speech therapy). General precautions included fall risk and right MCA CVA with evolution, status post TNK and thrombectomy, and dobhoff tube placement. The patient reported no pain. Cognitive evaluation revealed exceptions to within functional limits, with the patient alert and responsive but requiring repetition and increased time to follow one-step commands. Awareness of errors was decreased. Perceptual assessment showed inattention and neglect, requiring cues to maintain midline in sitting, attend to the left side of the body, and attend to the left visual field. The Modified Rankin Score was documented as 5. Bed mobility required maximum assistance of two with the head of the bed raised and bed rail towards the right side. Sitting balance was assessed, with the patient sitting at the edge of the bed for 10 minutes before becoming fatigued. Emphasis was placed on upright tolerance, postural control, and midline awareness. Improved head control was noted, aided by a soft travel neck pillow with towel rolls on the right side, brought in by the patient's wife. Maximum assistance was required for balance, with maximum verbal cueing to maintain head and trunk in neutral. Input was provided to bilateral scapulae to assist with postural control. During ADLs, the patient performed self-feeding while seated at the edge of the bed with speech therapy present. The patient was able to grasp a spoon and cup with the right upper extremity with standby assistance, requiring increased time to reach across midline to the left side of the environment. Visual tracking across midline to the left side was noted. Left shoulder subluxation was observed and elevated on two pillows at the end of treatment. The patient required maximum assistance to reach across midline with the right upper extremity to grasp and manipulate the left upper extremity. The patient was left in bed with the call light and essentials within reach, and the bed alarm was activated. The assessment indicated the patient was progressing as expected, with a recommendation to continue per the occupational therapy plan of care. The treatment plan included interventions 1-5 times per week, focusing on balance, ADL/IADL training, functional mobility and transfers, activity tolerance, therapeutic activity and exercise, range of motion, patient and family education, energy conservation, neuromuscular re-education, sensation, cognition, vision/perception, fine motor coordination, and upper extremity edema management. Discharge recommendations included continued post-acute therapy and intensive neuro-based inpatient rehabilitation.

events.title: Speech Therapy Progress Note
events.notes: At 13:00, the claimant participated in a speech therapy session with Kristen Schivera, CCC-SLP, at Memorial Health. The patient was awake, alert, and oriented but required increased time and repetition for commands. Oral trials of mildly thick liquids and puree revealed delayed swallowing and coughing. events.description_full: The patient was awake, alert, and agreeable to the speech therapy visit. The session occurred in the NICU/2617 while the patient was sitting at the edge of the bed with physical therapy present. The patient was currently NPO with dobhoff tube feeds and reported no pain. During the objective evaluation, the patient was given mildly thick liquids via straw and self-fed. Oral and pharyngeal function were within functional limits, but the patient exhibited an immediate cough and delayed swallow. Puree was presented via spoon and self-fed, with oral function within functional limits but delayed oral transit and delayed swallow noted. Cognitive and communication assessment revealed exceptions to within functional limits. The patient was alert and responsive, oriented to place, situation, and person, but required increased time and repetition to follow one-step commands. Thought organization showed mild impairment, and communication was noted to have exceptions to within functional limits, with improving cognitive deficits and decreased speech intelligibility. Cervical rotation to the left was performed five times prior to sitting at the edge of the bed. The patient required maximum assistance from occupational therapy to maintain the head in an upright and midline position for PO trials. Improved ability to self-correct position was noted during the session. The assessment indicated improving cognitive and communication deficits, with continued therapy recommended.

events.title: TNK administration for acute CVA
events.notes: At 07:52, the patient received TNK (tenecteplase) at an outside hospital as thrombolytic therapy for a right M1 occlusion associated with a large right MCA infarction. This was part of the acute management to restore perfusion and minimize ischemic damage. The treatment was followed by a partially successful aspiration and mechanical thrombectomy of the right MCA. The patient's response to TNK was not documented in this note.
events.description_full: The patient received TNK (tenecteplase) administration at 07:52 on 02/24/2023 at an outside hospital (OSH) as part of the acute management of a right M1 occlusion associated with a large right MCA infarction. This was administered as a thrombolytic therapy to address the acute cerebral vascular accident (CVA). The administration of TNK was part of the initial treatment protocol to restore perfusion and minimize ischemic damage. The patient's response to the medication was not documented in this specific note, but the treatment was followed by a partially successful aspiration and mechanical thrombectomy of the right MCA. The administration of TNK was a critical step in the acute management of the patient's condition.

events.title: Speech therapy progress note
events.notes: At 11:08, the patient was evaluated by speech therapy in the NICU. The patient, currently NPO with Dobhoff tube feeds, was cleared for puree and mildly thick liquids for comfort. Oral and pharyngeal function were within functional limits, though spillage was noted on the left side. Cognitively, the patient demonstrated mild impairments in thought organization and required cues for attention. No signs of aspiration were observed during PO trials. Recommendations included continued NPO status with Dobhoff feeds, compensatory swallowing strategies, and ongoing dysphagia and cognitive therapy.
events.description_full: The patient was seen in the NICU and was awake, alert, and agreeable to the speech therapy visit. The patient is currently NPO with Dobhoff tube feeds but was cleared for puree and mildly thick liquids for comfort the previous day. The patient's wife was present during the session. No pain was indicated. During the objective evaluation, the patient was given mildly thick liquids via straw and self-fed, with oral and pharyngeal function noted to be within functional limits. Puree was presented via spoon and self-fed, with oral function within functional limits but spillage noted on the left side. Pharyngeal function was within functional limits. Cognitively, the patient demonstrated exceptions to within functional limits, with mild impairment in thought organization and a need for cues to redirect attention. The patient followed most one-step commands without difficulty but with occasional delays. Functional communication was noted to be adequate for simple conversation and expressing wants/needs. Cervical rotation exercises to the left were completed with maximum cueing required. Oral motor exercises were completed, though the patient continued to show limited range of motion and strength. The patient demonstrated improved head control and positioning while sitting edge of bed, with continued improvement in self-correction. PO trials of pudding and mildly thick liquids were presented, with no overt signs or symptoms of aspiration observed. The patient showed improving cognition and awareness, allowing for the completion of compensatory strategies and oral motor exercises. Recommendations included continuing NPO status with Dobhoff tube feeds, allowing snacks of pudding and mildly thick liquids or carbonated drinks without thickener for comfort, and maintaining upright positioning during oral intake. Dysphagia treatment and cognitive therapy were recommended, with a plan to continue speech therapy during hospitalization. The patient was assessed to have a moderate aspiration risk, and compensatory swallowing strategies were recommended, including small bites/sips, slow eating/feeding, and one-to-one assistance with meals. Medications were recommended to be administered via feeding tube.

events.title: MRI Brain
events.notes: At 23:45, the patient underwent a multisequence MRI of the brain without intravenous contrast at Memorial Health. The imaging revealed an evolving large right middle cerebral artery (MCA) territory subacute infarction with petechial staining and a 1.2 cm leftward midline shift. A punctate cortical infarct was also noted in the left posterior frontal lobe. Mass effect and effacement of the right lateral ventricle were observed. The findings were consistent with significant cerebrovascular injury. The study was reviewed by Dr. Andreas Schilling, who finalized the report at 02:16 on February 26, 2023.
events.description_full: The patient underwent a multisequence MRI of the brain without intravenous contrast. The study was performed due to a history of acute cerebrovascular accident (CVA). Comparison was made to multiple prior imaging studies, with the most recent being a CT head on February 24, 2023. Findings included an evolving large right middle cerebral artery (MCA) territory subacute infarction with scattered regions of petechial staining and a resultant 1.2 cm leftward midline shift. Additionally, a punctate cortical infarct was noted in the left posterior frontal lobe. There was no abnormal brain parenchymal signal intensity, no significant volume loss, no mass or mass effect, and no extra-axial fluid collection. However, there was mass effect and effacement of the right lateral ventricle. The impression confirmed the evolving large right MCA territory subacute infarction with regions of hemosiderin deposition/petechial staining and the 1.2 cm leftward midline shift, as well as the additional punctate cortical infarct in the left posterior frontal lobe. The attending radiologist, Dr. Andreas Schilling, reviewed all images, agreed with the interpretation, and provided appropriate supervision for the exam. The MRI was performed between 23:45 on February 25, 2023, and 00:27 on February 26, 2023. The preliminary report was provided by Dr. Joshua Bloodworth, with the full report to follow from the attending radiologist.

events.notes: At 01:04, laboratory testing revealed hemoglobin at 11.8 g/dL and hematocrit at 36.5%, both slightly decreased. Sodium was mildly elevated at 147.07 mmol/L, chloride at 110.08 mmol/L, and CO2 at 35 mmol/L. Blood urea nitrogen was elevated at 30 mg/dL, and glucose was elevated at 166.50 mg/dL. Liver function tests showed elevated AST at 58 U/L and alkaline phosphatase at 136.19 U/L. These findings indicated ongoing metabolic derangements and hepatic stress, consistent with the patient's acute cerebrovascular condition.

BMP results revealed sodium (Na) at 147.07 mmol/L (slightly elevated), potassium (K) at 3.6 mmol/L (normal), chloride (Cl) at 110.08 mmol/L (elevated), CO2 at 35 mmol/L (elevated), blood urea nitrogen (BUN) at 30 mg/dL (elevated), creatinine at 0.97 mg/dL (normal), glucose (GLU) at 166.50 mg/dL (elevated), magnesium (MG) at 2.4 mg/dL (slightly low), and phosphorus (PHOS) at 3.36 mg/dL (normal). Liver function tests (LFTs) showed total protein (PROT) at 6.1 g/dL (normal), total bilirubin (BILITOT) at 0.4 mg/dL (normal), alanine aminotransferase (ALT) at 41 U/L (normal), aspartate aminotransferase (AST) at 58 U/L (elevated), and alkaline phosphatase (ALKPHOS) at 136.19 U/L (elevated). Coagulation studies, cardiac enzymes, arterial blood gases (ABG), lactate, and biomarkers were not available for this visit. The results indicate ongoing metabolic derangements, hyperglycemia, and liver enzyme elevation, consistent with the patient’s acute and chronic conditions.

events.title: Right Decompressive Hemicraniectomy and ICP Monitor Placement
events.notes: At 16:03, Dr. Daniel Suh performed a right decompressive hemicraniectomy and placed a subdural ICP monitor for a patient with a large right MCA infarction and worsening midline shift. The dura was opened, and decompression was achieved. A graft dura was implanted, and the wound was closed. The patient tolerated the procedure without complications and was transferred to the PACU in stable but critical condition.
events.description_full:
The patient, a 53-year-old male with a history of a large right MCA distribution infarction and associated mass effect with midline shift, underwent a right frontal temporal parietal decompressive hemi craniectomy and placement of a subdural ICP monitor. Preoperatively, the patient had left hemiparesis and left-sided neglect. He was initially treated medically with 3% normal saline and blood pressure management, followed by aspirin and Lovenox. Despite initial improvement, the patient developed increasing sleepiness and imaging (CT and MRI) revealed worsening midline shift. Due to neurological decline, emergent surgery was recommended. The patient and/or their representative were informed of the risks, benefits, and alternatives, including risks of death, neurological injury, bleeding, infection, and failure of symptom resolution. Consent was obtained. 

During the procedure, the patient was placed under general anesthesia with endotracheal intubation. A PICC line and arterial line were placed. Perioperative IV antibiotics (Rocephin) were administered, along with IV Lasix, 12 mg of Decadron, and a bolus of 250 cc of 3% normal saline, followed by a maintenance drip at 30 cc/hour. Sodium levels were monitored and maintained between 150-155. The patient was positioned in a Mayfield head holder, and a reversed question mark incision was made. Hemostasis was achieved using Raney clips, and a craniotome was used to create a bone flap, which was treated with antibiotics. The dura was opened in a horseshoe fashion, and the brain was noted to be full. Additional temporal bone was removed to allow for decompression. The middle meningeal artery was cauterized, and the subdural space was irrigated with antibiotic-laden saline until clear. FloSeal was applied for hemostasis. A subdural ICP monitor was placed through a separate stab incision and secured. The dura was covered with DuraGen, and the wound was closed with interrupted sutures and running nylon. Bacitracin ointment and a sterile dressing were applied. 

The patient tolerated the procedure without apparent complications. Needle, sponge, and instrument counts were correct. The patient was kept intubated and transferred to the recovery room in stable but critical condition.

events.title: Transfusion Reaction Checklist
events.notes: On 2023-02-28, the patient, Frank Ward, experienced a transfusion reaction during blood product administration. Symptoms included itching, nausea, respiratory distress, and a temperature increase. The transfusion was stopped immediately, and the IV line was kept open. Identification was verified, and the physician was notified. A transfusion reaction workup was ordered, and the remaining blood product was sent to the blood bank. The patient was educated on symptoms to report. The blood product administered was SDP ACD-A PASCLRPRZ (AB Pos), with no compatibility testing required. The transfusion reaction checklist was completed and signed off by the care team.
events.description_full: The patient, Frank Ward (MRN: 40162221, DOB: 11/12/1969), experienced a transfusion reaction during the administration of blood products. Documented symptoms included itching, nausea/vomiting, respiratory distress, and other potential signs such as temperature increase of 2 or more degrees Fahrenheit or 1 Celsius, decrease of 20-30 mmHg systolic blood pressure, hematuria, chills, abdominal/back pain, and rash. The transfusion was stopped immediately, and the IV line was kept open. The patient's armband was compared with the blood bag label to verify identification. The physician was notified, and the reaction was documented in Epic. A copy of the flowsheet was printed and sent to the blood bank along with the remaining blood, administration set, and attached IV solutions. Orders for a transfusion reaction workup were entered into the computer system. Instructions included sending the first voided urine sample when requested. The patient verbalized understanding of the signs and symptoms to report. Blood consent was signed, and all fields in the transfusion documentation were completed. The blood product administered was SDP ACD-A PASCLRPRZ (Product Code Literal: E8342V00), with ABO/Rh compatibility noted as AB Pos. Compatibility testing was not performed, and the crossmatch interpretation was marked as 'Not Required.' The expiration date and time of the blood product were documented as 04/13/2023 at 23:59. The transfusion reaction checklist was completed by the RN/MD/AA/CRNA, and the event was signed off accordingly.

events.title: Tracheostomy placement
events.notes: The patient underwent a tracheostomy performed by Dr. Watson due to complications from acute hypoxemic respiratory failure and airway management issues. The patient had been intubated on 2/27/2023, extubated on 3/6/2023, and reintubated on 3/7/2023 due to mucus plugging. A bronchoscopy on 3/7/2023 revealed left main bronchus obstruction. Cultures identified Candida parapsilosis on 3/4/2023, and a subsequent BAL on 3/17/2023 revealed MSSA and pseudomonas. The tracheostomy provided a stable airway, and no immediate complications were noted.
events.description_full: The patient, a 53-year-old male with a history of acute right MCA M1 occlusion, underwent a tracheostomy on 3/10/2023. This procedure was performed following a series of complications related to acute hypoxemic respiratory failure and recurrent issues with airway management. The patient had been intubated on 2/27/2023 for a procedure and remained intubated postoperatively. He was extubated on 3/6/2023 but required reintubation on 3/7/2023 due to mucus plugging. A bronchoscopy performed on 3/7/2023 revealed complete obstruction of the left main bronchus, and bronchial washing was conducted. Lower respiratory cultures from 3/4/2023 identified Candida parapsilosis, while a BAL performed on 3/7/2023 was negative. The tracheostomy was performed to provide a more stable airway and address the ongoing respiratory challenges. The patient’s clinical course was complicated by right basilar pneumonia with MSSA and pseudomonas, which were identified in a subsequent BAL on 3/17/2023. The procedure was performed by Dr. Watson, and no immediate complications were documented.

events.description_full: The patient, Frank Ward, was evaluated by Kara Scott, OT, on March 13, 2023, at 13:50. The patient’s active problem list includes cerebral vascular accident (CVA), hypertensive emergency, diabetes mellitus type 2 in obesity, and status post craniotomy. Precautions noted include right MCA CVA with evolution, status post TNK and thrombectomy, increased midline shift with left craniectomy, right wrist restraint, helmet, and trach to vent. Bilateral upper extremity (UE) range of motion (ROM) was provided in all joints and planes for sensory input and musculoskeletal integrity. The patient resisted ROM in the right upper extremity (RUE), while left upper extremity (LUE) ROM was noted as within functional limits (WFL). The patient was left in bed as found, with the right wrist restraint in place. The assessment concluded that the patient would continue to benefit from skilled occupational therapy services to promote safety and independence in activities of daily living (ADLs) and functional mobility.

events.description_full: The patient was noted to have a tracheostomy to a ventilator, was non-verbal, and was not following simple verbal commands. Precautions included right middle cerebral artery (R MCA) cerebrovascular accident (CVA) with evolution, status post (s/p) TNK administration and thrombectomy, increased midline shift with left craniectomy, right wrist restraint, helmet, and tracheostomy to ventilator. The patient did not rate pain. Upon evaluation, the patient was supine in bed. Passive range of motion (PROM) was performed bilaterally on the lower extremities (B LEs) for 10 repetitions in all planes to the patient’s tolerance. PROM was within functional limits (WFL) with good tolerance. PROM was performed to maintain range of motion and joint integrity and to facilitate future mobility. The patient’s lower extremities were positioned using a pillow and wedge to facilitate neutral alignment. The patient was left in bed with needs within reach, and all lines and tubes were in place. The assessment noted decreased functional ability, balance, activity tolerance, and lower extremity strength, as well as impaired transfers, tone, and cognition. The patient was at fall risk, had impaired safe judgment, and required 24/7 care. The Modified Rankin Score was documented as 5. The physical therapist recommended continued post-acute therapy with interventions including gait training, endurance exercises, transfer training, bed mobility, therapeutic exercises, strengthening, balance training, neuro re-education, patient and family education, equipment evaluation, stair training, range of motion exercises, and wheelchair mobility. The session was electronically signed by Kendra Smith, PT, at 13:28.

events.title: Occupational Therapy Treatment-Inpatient
events.notes: At 13:17, the claimant underwent occupational therapy at Memorial Health. The patient, agreeable to therapy, required total assistance for supine scooting and demonstrated a Modified Rankin Score of 5. Active-assisted range of motion (AAROM) was performed on the right upper extremity, and passive range of motion (PROM) was conducted on the left upper extremity. Oxygen saturation declined to 89-90% post-activity, prompting notification of respiratory therapy. Recommendations included continued skilled therapy to promote safety and independence in ADLs and functional mobility, with discharge to a long-term acute care facility.
events.description_full: The patient was received in bed and was agreeable to therapy. No complaints of pain were noted during the session. Objective evaluation included a Modified Rankin Score of 5. The patient required total assistance for supine scooting to the head of the bed. The bed was placed in a chair position, and the patient opened their eyes with increased stimuli but was unable to maintain them open. Active-assisted range of motion (AAROM) was performed for the right upper extremity to assess strength, activity tolerance, and musculoskeletal integrity. Passive range of motion (PROM) was performed for the left upper extremity. Heart rate was documented in the 90-100s. Following activity, the bed was reclined, and the patient’s oxygen saturation declined to 89-90%. Respiratory therapy (RT) was notified. The patient was left in bed with all needs within reach. The assessment indicated that the patient would continue to benefit from skilled occupational therapy services to promote safety and independence in activities of daily living (ADLs) and functional mobility. Discharge recommendations included continued post-acute therapy and transfer to a long-term acute care (LTAC) facility. Goals and the treatment plan were discussed and agreed upon with the patient.

events.notes: At 14:53, the claimant underwent physical therapy at Memorial Health. events.description_full: The patient was supine in bed upon the therapist’s arrival and was on a 35% trach collar. The patient was unable to follow simple verbal commands and did not verbalize during the session. Precautions included right middle cerebral artery (R MCA) CVA with evolution, status post TNK and thrombectomy, increased midline shift with left craniectomy, right wrist restraint, helmet, and 35% trach collar. Pain was not rated by the patient. During the session, the patient required total assistance for scooting in bed. The patient was placed in a chair position for 5 minutes but demonstrated increased work of breathing and decreased sitting tolerance. Oxygen saturation was documented at 92-93% with a heart rate of 102 while in the chair position. Upon returning to a supine position, the patient experienced desaturation to 89%. Respiratory therapy (RT) was notified and remained in the room. The patient was left in bed with all needs within reach, and all lines and tubes were secured. The assessment noted decreased functional ability, balance, and activity tolerance, as well as impaired transfers, fall risk, decreased lower extremity strength, and impaired cognition. The Modified Rankin Score was 5. The plan included interventions such as gait training, endurance exercises, transfer training, bed mobility, therapeutic exercises, strengthening, balance training, neuro re-education, patient and family education, equipment evaluation, stair training, range of motion (ROM) exercises, and wheelchair mobility. Discharge recommendations included continued post-acute therapy with 24/7 care, with ongoing assessment as the patient progresses.

events.title: Physical Therapy Progress Note
events.notes: At 14:15, the patient, Frank Ward, was evaluated by physical therapy following a right MCA stroke with complications including cerebral edema, craniectomy, and ventilator dependence. The session focused on passive range of motion (PROM) for both lower extremities to maintain joint integrity and mobility. The patient required maximum assistance for hygiene and repositioning. Assessment noted significant disability (Modified Rankin Score 5), fall risk, and generalized weakness. Recommendations included continued physical therapy post-acute discharge, emphasizing gait training, strengthening, and neuro re-education. The session lasted 26 minutes.
events.description_full: The patient, Frank Ward, was supine in bed and cleared for therapy by the registered nurse. The patient required a linen change due to an ice pack leak. Precautions included fall risk, right middle cerebral artery (MCA) cerebrovascular accident (CVA) with evolution, status post TNK administration and thrombectomy, increased midline shift with left craniectomy, right wrist restraint, helmet, and 35% tracheostomy to ventilator. The patient was unable to report pain but was repositioned for comfort after treatment. Cognitive evaluation revealed the patient was sleepy but arousable and had exceptions to within functional limits (WFL) in direction following. During therapy, the patient was log-rolled left and right multiple times with maximum to total assistance from two individuals for hygiene and linen change. He was kept in a side-lying position for an extended time for hygiene and linen change before being returned to supine and scooted up in bed with total assistance from two individuals. Passive range of motion (PROM) was performed on both lower extremities to maintain range of motion and joint integrity and facilitate future mobility. The patient was left in bed with the call light and essentials within reach, the bed alarm activated, and all lines and tubes in place. The assessment noted a decline in ambulation, decreased lower extremity strength, decreased safe judgment, decreased activity tolerance, gait instability, fall risk, decreased balance, decreased functional ability, decreased high-level ADLs, generalized weakness, impaired gait, and impaired transfers. The Modified Rankin Score was 5, indicating significant disability. The prognosis was good for stated goals, and the patient remained in ICU/critical care. Recommendations included continued physical therapy post-acute discharge, focusing on gait training, endurance, transfer training, bed mobility, therapeutic exercise, therapeutic activity, strengthening, balance, neuro re-education, patient and family education, equipment evaluation and education, stair training, range of motion, and wheelchair mobility 3-5 times per week. The session lasted 26 minutes, from 11:00 to 11:26.

events.title: CBC and BMP
events.notes: At 05:17, laboratory tests including a CBC and BMP were performed. The CBC revealed leukocytosis (WBC 12.2), anemia (hemoglobin 7.4, hematocrit 23.9), and normal platelet count (347). The BMP showed hypernatremia (sodium 147.11), hyperchloremia (chloride 113.29), hyperglycemia (glucose 173.59), and elevated BUN (29), with normal creatinine (0.86). These findings indicate ongoing critical illness with metabolic derangements and anemia, consistent with the patient’s clinical condition.
events.description_full: Laboratory results from 03/18/2023 at 05:17 included a CBC and BMP. The CBC showed a WBC count of 12.2 (elevated), hemoglobin of 7.4 (low), hematocrit of 23.9 (low), MCV of 93.0 (normal), and platelet count of 347 (normal). The BMP revealed sodium at 147.11 (elevated), potassium at 4.1 (normal), chloride at 113.29 (elevated), CO2 at 33 (elevated), BUN at 29 (elevated), creatinine at 0.86 (normal), glucose at 173.59 (elevated), magnesium at 2.5 (elevated), and phosphorus at 4.09 (normal). These findings indicate ongoing electrolyte imbalances and anemia, consistent with the patient's critical condition. No additional biomarkers, cardiac enzymes, or coagulation studies were available for this time point.

events.title: Chest X-ray AP
events.notes: At 06:21, the patient underwent a chest X-ray AP view to evaluate respiratory failure. Findings included increased hazy opacity in the right lung, likely representing layering effusion, and improved aeration of the left lung base with residual discoid atelectasis. The cardiomediastinal silhouette was moderately enlarged but stable. A tracheostomy tube was visualized in the mid-thoracic trachea, and a nasogastric tube was noted below the diaphragm. Interval removal of the left PICC line was documented. The report was reviewed and signed by Dr. Brandon Runyan at 07:38.
events.description_full: The patient underwent a chest X-ray AP view on 03/18/2023 at 06:21. The imaging was performed to evaluate respiratory failure, with a comparison to a prior chest X-ray from 03/10/2023. Findings included increased hazy opacity in the right lung, likely representing layering effusion with right mid and lower lung opacity. There was improved aeration of the left lung base with residual discoid atelectasis and plate-like atelectasis of the left base. The cardiomediastinal silhouette was noted to be moderately enlarged but stable. Bones and soft tissues appeared normal for the patient’s age. A tracheostomy tube was visualized with its tip overlying the mid-thoracic trachea. The nasogastric tube was noted to be below the diaphragm and out of the field of view. Interval removal of the left PICC line was also documented. The attending radiologist reviewed all images, agreed with the interpretation, and provided appropriate supervision for the exam. The report was electronically signed by Brandon Runyan, MD, at 07:38.

events.title: X-ray KUB with Contrast Tube Placement
events.notes: The patient underwent an X-ray KUB with contrast to confirm gastrostomy tube placement following new onset drainage and bruising noted by family. Two AP images were obtained before and after contrast administration via the G-tube. Findings included a nonobstructive bowel gas pattern and a well-positioned gastrostomy tube. Post-contrast images showed oral contrast filling the gastric lumen without evidence of extravasation or extraluminal air. Bones showed no acute fractures, and soft tissues appeared normal. The attending radiologist reviewed all images and confirmed the interpretation.
events.description_full: The patient underwent an X-ray KUB with contrast tube placement to confirm tube location due to new onset drainage and bruising noted by family. Two AP images were obtained before and after administration of contrast via G-tube. Findings included a nonobstructive bowel gas pattern and a gastrostomy tube in place. Post-contrast imaging demonstrated oral contrast filling the gastric lumen with no evidence of extravasation. No extraluminal air was observed. Bones showed no acute fracture or concerning osseous lesion, and soft tissues appeared normal. Impression noted that the gastrostomy tube was well-positioned with no evidence of contrast extravasation from the stomach. The attending radiologist reviewed all images, agreed with the interpretation, and provided appropriate supervision for the exam.

The plan included interventions such as gait training, endurance exercises, transfer training, bed mobility, therapeutic exercises, strengthening, balance training, neuro re-education, patient and family education, equipment evaluation, stair training, range of motion exercises, and wheelchair mobility. Ventilation was set to assist control (AC) mode with observed tidal volumes ranging from 230 mL to 482 mL and a set tidal volume of 500 mL. Respiratory rate was documented as 14 breaths per minute, with peak inspiratory pressures ranging from 16 to 24 cm H2O. End-tidal CO2 levels were recorded between 37.8 mmHg and 40.9 mmHg. Oxygen saturation remained at 100% throughout the procedure. The patient was noted to be in sinus rhythm on EKG monitoring. The anesthesia was discontinued at 11:49, with no complications reported. The patient remained stable post-anesthesia.

events.notes: At 09:43, Dr. John S. Solitario conducted a pre-procedure anesthesia evaluation. The patient, a 53-year-old male with a history of cerebrovascular accident and diabetes, was assessed for general anesthesia (ASA 4) prior to PEG tube placement. No history of anesthetic complications was noted. Airway assessment revealed no increased risk of difficulty, and pulmonary and cardiovascular exams were normal. The anesthesia plan included intravenous induction, and risks were discussed with the patient. The evaluation was electronically signed at 10:39.
events.description_full: The patient underwent a pre-procedure anesthesia evaluation conducted by Dr. John S Solitario. The patient summary and nursing notes were reviewed. There was no history of anesthetic complications. The airway was assessed, and no increased risk of difficult airway was noted. The patient was intubated, and the Mallampati score was documented. Pulmonary examination was normal, though the patient reported shortness of breath. Cardiovascular examination was normal, but the patient had a history of hypertension. Neurological and psychiatric history included a cerebrovascular accident (CVA). Endocrine history was significant for diabetes mellitus. Abdominal examination was normal. The anesthesia plan was documented as ASA 4 general anesthesia with intravenous induction. The risks and plan were discussed with the patient. The evaluation was electronically signed by Dr. Solitario at 10:39.

events.title: Surgery Progress Note
events.notes: At 09:49, Dr. Shawn Barker evaluated the patient, a 53-year-old male with a history of right MCA stroke and dysphagia, in preparation for PEG placement. The patient was minimally responsive with a GCS score of 9T. Physical exam revealed a tracheostomy, hemostatic craniectomy site, and ventilated breath sounds. Labs showed elevated WBC (14.6), low hemoglobin (8.3), and metabolic alkalosis. The patient was NPO for the procedure. The surgical plan was to proceed with PEG placement later that day.
events.description_full: The patient, a 53-year-old male with a history of a recent right MCA stroke and persistent dysphagia, was evaluated for PEG placement. The patient was noted to be minimally responsive during the physical exam. Vitals at 06:00 included blood pressure of 139/83, pulse of 73, respiratory rate of 28, and SpO2 of 97%. The patient was wearing a helmet with evidence of a right craniectomy. Pupils were round and reactive. A tracheostomy was in place, and the site was hemostatic. Cardiovascular examination revealed a regular rate and rhythm. Pulmonary examination showed ventilated breath sounds bilaterally. The abdomen was soft, non-distended, and protuberant. Neurological assessment revealed a GCS score of 9T (E3 VT M5). Skin was warm and well-perfused. Labs from the same day showed elevated WBC at 14.6, low hemoglobin at 8.3, low hematocrit at 27.8, elevated MCV at 95.9, and normal platelets at 400. Electrolytes included sodium at 149.81 (high), potassium at 3.6 (normal), chloride at 111.94 (high), CO2 at 36 (high), anion gap at 5 (low), glucose at 141.84 (high), BUN at 30 (high), creatinine at 0.92 (normal), and calcium at 7.6 (low). The patient was NPO in preparation for PEG placement later in the day. The surgical plan was to proceed with PEG placement in the operating room. The note was electronically signed by Dr. Shawn Barker at 09:51.

events.provider: Dr. Sarah Ellen E. Stephens, MD
events.title: Critical Care Medicine Progress Note
events.notes: At 09:58, Dr. Sarah Ellen E. Stephens evaluated the patient on hospital day 32. The patient, with a history of right MCA stroke and respiratory failure, remained stable overnight and was NPO for PEG placement. Labs revealed elevated sodium (149) and metabolic alkalosis (bicarbonate 36). Physical exam showed diminished breath sounds at the right base, dense left hemiparesis, and inconsistent response to commands. The patient participated in physical and occupational therapy. Ventilator settings included PRVC mode with FiO2 at 40%. The patient required ongoing ventilator support and glycemic control.
events.description_full: The patient, a 53-year-old male with a history of a right MCA stroke, cerebral edema, and respiratory failure, was evaluated on hospital day 32. Overnight, the patient remained stable and was NPO in preparation for PEG placement. Glycemic control was adequate on a reduced dose of Lantus. Sodium was elevated at 149, and metabolic alkalosis was noted with bicarbonate at 36. Hemoglobin was stable at 8.3. A bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) performed the previous day showed continued growth of Gram-negative rods. The patient participated in physical therapy and occupational therapy, sitting up at the edge of the bed. Vital signs included a temperature range of 37.1–37.2°C, heart rate of 73, respiratory rate of 28, and blood pressure of 139/83. Intake and output over the last 24 hours showed a net negative balance of -1350 mL. The physical exam revealed a tracheostomy with ventilator support, diminished breath sounds at the right base, a soft and distended abdomen, dense left hemiparesis, and inconsistent response to commands on the right side. The patient remained critically ill, requiring ongoing ventilator support, glycemic control, and preparation for PEG placement.
