events.title: Percutaneous Endoscopic Gastrostomy (PEG) Tube Placement
events.notes: At 10:05, Dr. William J. Bromberg performed a PEG tube placement for dysphagia. The patient was sedated, and the procedure was completed under direct visualization. The stomach was accessed percutaneously, and the PEG tube was successfully placed without complications. Estimated blood loss was minimal, and findings included a normal upper GI endoscopy. The patient tolerated the procedure well.
events.description_full: The patient underwent a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube placement performed by Dr. William J Bromberg, with assistance from Dr. Shawn J. Barker (PGY5) and Dr. Brenna Casey (PGY2). The procedure was indicated for dysphagia. The patient was identified, and time-out protocols were followed. The patient was sedated and placed in the supine position. A protective bite block was placed, and an endoscope was advanced through the upper esophageal sphincter into the stomach under direct visualization. The stomach and gastroesophageal junction were fully visualized, and the pylorus was identified. The endoscope was advanced into the duodenum, where the first and second portions were visualized. The anterior abdominal wall was palpated, and the area of best impulse and transillumination was selected. The area was marked, prepared, and draped in a sterile fashion. Local anesthesia with 1% lidocaine and epinephrine was administered. A 1 cm incision was made, and the stomach was accessed percutaneously with a needle/catheter under direct visualization. The catheter was grasped with a snare, and the pull wire was placed through the catheter into the stomach. The wire was then grasped and withdrawn carefully. The PEG tube was fastened to the pull wire, drawn down the esophagus into the stomach, and brought through the abdominal wall with gentle traction. The procedure was completed without complications. Estimated blood loss was minimal. Findings included a normal upper GI endoscopy. The procedure was documented as successful, and the patient tolerated it well.

events.title: Lab Results
events.notes: At 00:06, laboratory results revealed significant electrolyte imbalances and mild renal dysfunction. Sodium was elevated at 150.86 mMOL/L, potassium was low at 3.3 mMOL/L, and chloride was high at 114.80 mMOL/L. Hemoglobin was decreased to 7.5 g/dL, and hematocrit was 25.5%. Calcium was low at 7.3 mg/dL. Platelet count was normal at 365 x10^9/L. These findings were consistent with ongoing critical care management and were reviewed for monitoring purposes.
events.description_full: Laboratory results from 00:06 on 03/22/2023 included the following: sodium 150.86 mMOL/L (high, reference range 137-145 mMOL/L), potassium 3.3 mMOL/L (low, reference range 3.5-5.1 mMOL/L), chloride 114.80 mMOL/L (high, reference range 98-107 mMOL/L), CO2 37 mMOL/L (high, reference range 21-31 mMOL/L), anion gap 2 (low, reference range 3-11), glucose 90.16 mg/dL (reference range 70-110 mg/dL), BUN 25 mg/dL (high, reference range 9-21 mg/dL), creatinine 0.91 mg/dL (reference range 0.52-1.25 mg/dL), and calcium 7.3 mg/dL (low, reference range 8.5-10.5 mg/dL). These results were consistent with ongoing electrolyte imbalances and mild renal dysfunction. The patient’s hemoglobin was noted to have decreased to 7.5 g/dL (low, reference range 13.5-17.5 g/dL), and hematocrit was 25.5% (low, reference range 38.8-50%). Platelet count was 365 x10^9/L (normal, reference range 150-450 x10^9/L). The results were reviewed as part of ongoing monitoring for the patient’s critical care management.

events.title: Surgery Progress Note
events.notes: At 08:07, Dr. Shawn Barker evaluated the patient following PEG placement performed on 03/21/2023. The patient was minimally responsive, with vitals showing a pulse of 86 bpm and SpO2 at 96%. Physical examination revealed a helmet in place due to a right craniectomy, a hemostatic tracheostomy site, and a functioning PEG tube with visible gastric contents. Neurological assessment showed a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 9T. Laboratory results indicated electrolyte imbalances, including elevated sodium at 150.86 mMOL/L and low potassium at 3.3 mMOL/L. The PEG tube was deemed appropriate for feeds and medications, with T-bars to remain in place for two weeks. General surgery planned to sign off.
events.description_full: The patient was noted to be doing well following PEG placement. Physical examination revealed the following: blood pressure was not documented, pulse was 86, respiratory rate was not documented, temperature was not documented, and SpO2 was 96%. The patient was minimally responsive. HEENT examination showed a helmet in place with evidence of a right craniectomy, and pupils were round and reactive. The neck examination revealed a tracheostomy in place with a hemostatic site. Cardiovascular examination showed a regular rate and rhythm. Pulmonary examination revealed ventilated breath sounds bilaterally. The abdomen was soft, non-distended, and protuberant, with a PEG in place and gastric contents visible in the tubing. A binder was in place. Neurological examination showed a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 9T (E3 VT M5). The skin was warm and well-perfused. Laboratory results included a WBC of 10.6, hemoglobin of 7.5 (low), hematocrit of 25.5 (low), MCV of 97.0 (high), and platelets of 365. Electrolytes showed sodium of 150.86 (high), potassium of 3.3 (low), chloride of 114.80 (high), CO2 of 37 (high), anion gap of 2 (low), glucose of 90.16, BUN of 25 (high), creatinine of 0.91, and calcium of 7.3 (low). The patient was noted to have a recent right MCA stroke with persistent dysphagia. General surgery was consulted for PEG placement, which was completed on 03/21/2023. The PEG was deemed appropriate for tube feeds and medications. T-bars were to remain in place for two weeks, and general surgery planned to sign off.

events.title: Critical Care Medicine Progress Note
events.notes: At 09:36, Dr. Sarah Ellen E Stephens evaluated the patient, a 53-year-old male with a history of right MCA stroke, cerebral edema, and respiratory failure. The patient was stable overnight except for mild hyperglycemia. Tube feeds resumed following PEG placement on 03/21/2023. Repeat BAL showed MRSA with a vancomycin MIC of 2. The patient was more awake, mouthing words, and obeying commands. Vitals included a temperature of 36.7-37.0°C, heart rate of 86 bpm, and blood pressure of 135/87 mmHg. Neurological exam revealed dense left hemiparesis and improved command following on the right. The patient remained ventilated on PRVC mode with FiO2 at 40%. Medications included linezolid and piperacillin-tazobactam.
events.description_full: The patient, a 53-year-old male with a history of a right MCA stroke, cerebral edema, and respiratory failure, was noted to have been stable overnight except for mild hyperglycemia. The patient remained ventilated and afebrile. He was status post PEG placement on 03/21/2023, which he tolerated well. Tube feeds were cleared to resume this morning. Sodium was 150, potassium was 2.3, and creatinine was stable. There was a mild drop in hemoglobin to 7.5 from 8.3, with no signs of bleeding. Repeat BAL was now growing MRSA with a vancomycin MIC of 2. The patient was more awake and interactive, mouthing words. Physical examination revealed a temperature range of 36.7–37.0°C, heart rate of 86, respiratory rate of 15, and blood pressure of 135/87. Intake and output over the last 24 hours showed a net negative balance of -1184.58 mL. The Glasgow Coma Scale was non-testable due to factors interfering with communication, but the patient opened eyes to voice and obeyed commands. HEENT examination showed right temporal post-craniotomy changes without edema or drainage. Cardiovascular examination revealed a normal rate and rhythm with palpable distal pulses. Pulmonary examination showed ventilator assistance with diffusely diminished breath sounds and no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi. The abdomen was soft, non-tender, distended, with positive bowel sounds, and the PEG site was hemostatic. Neurological examination showed dense left hemiparesis and more consistent following of commands on the right. The patient had a tracheostomy in place and was on a ventilator with PRVC mode, FiO2 of 40%, set PEEP of 6 cmH2O, and a tidal volume of 500 mL. Medications included amlodipine, artificial tears, aspirin, atorvastatin, chlorhexidine, enoxaparin, famotidine, insulin glargine, insulin lispro, linezolid, piperacillin-tazobactam, and lactated Ringer's. Laboratory results showed a WBC of 10.6, hemoglobin of 7.5 (low), hematocrit of 25.5 (low), MCV of 97.0 (high), platelets of 365, sodium of 150.86 (high), potassium of 3.3 (low), chloride of 114.80 (high), CO2 of 37 (high), anion gap of 2 (low), glucose of 90.16, BUN of 25 (high), creatinine of 0.91, calcium of 7.3 (low), and liver function tests showing ALT of 83, AST of 94, and alkaline phosphatase of 249.66.

events.title: Physical Therapy Progress Note
events.notes: At 13:41, the claimant was evaluated by Kendra Smith, PT. The patient required total assistance to transition from supine to sitting on the edge of the bed (EOB) and demonstrated decreased trunk control and left-sided flaccidity. Sitting tolerance improved with time and stable vitals on the trach collar. The assessment noted generalized weakness, impaired transfers, and fall risk. Recommendations included gait training, strengthening, and neuro re-education. The session was electronically signed at 13:47.
events.description_full: The patient was evaluated by Kendra Smith, PT, at 13:41. The patient was supine in bed upon entry and required total assistance to transition from supine to sitting on the edge of the bed (EOB). Sitting on the EOB required maximum assistance, with decreased pushing noted on the left side due to flaccidity. Efforts were made to perform anterior weight shifts to improve trunk control, but the patient demonstrated decreased initiation to maintain trunk control. However, sitting tolerance improved with increased time and stable vitals while on the trach collar. The patient transitioned from sitting to supine with total assistance and was left in bed in a chair position with all lines and tubes in place. The patient’s wife was present in the room during the session. The assessment noted generalized weakness, decreased functional ability, decreased activity tolerance, decreased balance, fall risk, impaired transfers, impaired gait, decreased safe judgment, decreased lower extremity strength, and decreased cognition. The Modified Rankin Score was documented as 4. Recommendations included gait training, endurance, transfer training, bed mobility, therapeutic exercise, therapeutic activity, strengthening, balance, neuro re-education, patient/family education, equipment evaluation/education, stair training, range of motion exercises, and wheelchair mobility. The session was electronically signed by Kendra Smith, PT, at 13:47.

events.title: Occupational Therapy Treatment
events.notes: At 15:15, the claimant was evaluated by Kara Scott, OT. The patient transitioned from supine to sitting with maximum assistance and participated in therapy focusing on sitting balance and upright tolerance. Fatigue limited progress, but oxygen saturation remained above 98% on the trach collar. The patient was left in bed in a chair position with improved positioning. The Modified Rankin Score was documented as 5. The session was electronically signed at 15:22.
events.description_full: The patient was evaluated by Kara Scott, OT, at 15:15. The patient was fatigued from prior bedpan toileting and bathing but roused with stimuli and was agreeable to participate in therapy. The patient transitioned from supine to sitting on the right side of the bed with maximum assistance from two individuals. Therapy focused on sitting balance, upright tolerance, body awareness, and positioning in space. Initially, the patient required maximum assistance for sitting balance but was able to achieve standby assistance for head control. Pillows were placed under the left upper extremity to improve joint positioning and integrity. As the session progressed, the patient required moderate assistance to maintain midline head control due to fatigue. Therapy promoted posterior lean with focus on engaging the core for return to an upright sitting position, but the patient demonstrated decreased engagement of the core for this task. Oxygen saturation remained above 98% on the trach collar throughout the session. The patient transitioned from sitting to supine with total assistance and was left in bed in a chair position with pillows under the upper extremities for improved positioning. The patient was left in bed with needs within reach. The Modified Rankin Score was documented as 5. The session was electronically signed by Kara Scott, OT, at 15:22.

events.title: Physical Therapy Progress Note
events.notes: At 12:54, the claimant was evaluated by Kendra Smith, PT, for a physical therapy progress note. The patient was supine in bed, and passive range of motion (PROM) was performed on bilateral lower extremities with good tolerance. PROM was within functional limits and aimed to maintain joint integrity. The left lower extremity was positioned in neutral to reduce external rotation. The assessment noted decreased functional ability, balance, and strength, with the left side flaccid and the right side showing spontaneous movement but not to command. The patient was identified as a fall risk and was preparing for dialysis. Discharge recommendations included post-acute therapy and transfer to a long-term acute care facility.
events.description_full: The patient was evaluated by Kendra Smith, PT, for a physical therapy progress note. The patient was noted to be supine in bed upon entry. Passive range of motion (PROM) was performed on bilateral lower extremities (B LEs) for 10 repetitions in all planes to the patient’s tolerance. PROM was within functional limits (WFL) with good tolerance. PROM was performed to maintain range of motion (ROM) and joint integrity to facilitate future mobility. The left lower extremity (L LE) was positioned in neutral with a wedge to decrease left hip external rotation (ER). The patient was left in bed with all needs within reach and all lines and tubes in place. The assessment noted decreased functional ability, balance, activity tolerance, and strength in both upper and lower extremities. The patient was identified as a fall risk with impaired gait, transfers, and judgment. The left side was flaccid with spontaneous movement on the right side but not to command. The patient was back on a trach to vent and preparing to initiate dialysis. The plan included gait training, endurance exercises, transfer training, bed mobility, therapeutic exercises, strengthening, balance training, neuro re-education, patient and family education, equipment evaluation, stair training, ROM exercises, and wheelchair mobility. Discharge recommendations included continued post-acute therapy and transfer to a long-term acute care (LTAC) facility. The evaluation time was documented as 10 minutes.

events.title: Occupational Therapy Treatment
events.notes: At 13:22, the claimant was evaluated by Kara Scott, OT, for an occupational therapy session. The patient, in bed and agreeable to therapy, demonstrated a Modified Rankin Score of 5. Limited eye tracking and scanning were noted, with no command-following in the right upper extremity. Active-assisted range of motion (AAROM) was performed on the right upper extremity, and passive range of motion (PROM) was performed on the left upper extremity, limited by glenohumeral subluxation. The patient was left in bed with all needs within reach. The assessment recommended continued skilled occupational therapy to promote safety and independence in activities of daily living. Discharge planning included transfer to a long-term acute care facility.
events.description_full: The patient was evaluated by Kara Scott, OT, for an occupational therapy treatment session. The patient was received in bed and was agreeable to therapy. The patient’s wife was present at the bedside. The patient did not report any pain during the session. Objective findings included a Modified Rankin Score of 5. The patient’s eyes opened but demonstrated very limited tracking and scanning. The eyes were able to rest at midline and intermittently to the left of midline without nystagmus. The patient did not follow commands with the right upper extremity (RUE). Active-assisted range of motion (AAROM) was performed on the RUE with resistance in full shoulder flexion. Passive range of motion (PROM) was performed on the left upper extremity (LUE) in all joints and planes, with limited shoulder flexion due to glenohumeral (GH) joint subluxation. The patient was left in bed with all needs within reach. The assessment indicated that the patient would continue to benefit from skilled occupational therapy services to promote safety and independence in activities of daily living (ADLs) and functional mobility. Discharge recommendations included continued post-acute therapy and transfer to a long-term acute care (LTAC) facility. The treatment time was documented as 9 minutes. Goals and the treatment plan were discussed and agreed upon with the patient.

events.title: Consent for Bronchoscopy and Related Procedures
events.notes: At 13:00, the claimant provided consent for a bronchoscopy to be performed by Dr. Casey H. Morris or a designee at Memorial Health. The consent form outlined the procedure, potential risks, benefits, and alternatives. The claimant also consented to anesthesia, blood transfusion, and the participation of medical personnel under supervision. The form was signed by the claimant's wife as an authorized representative, with a witness signature documented.
events.description_full: The patient, Frank Ward, provided consent for a proposed procedure to be performed in Room 2602. The procedure listed was a bronchoscopy. The consent form detailed that Dr. Casey H. Morris or a designee would perform the procedure, with the possibility of additional operations or procedures being conducted if deemed necessary based on findings during the operation. The patient acknowledged that no guarantee or assurance was made regarding the outcomes. The patient was informed that medical personnel might assist in the procedure under the direct supervision of the doctor. The purpose, benefits, potential risks, and alternative methods of treatment were explained to the patient, who confirmed understanding of the explanation. The patient consented to the administration of anesthetics and/or sedation, which may be administered and monitored by an anesthesiologist, a certified registered nurse anesthetist, or an anesthesia assistant under the medical direction of an anesthesiologist. Risks associated with the procedure were outlined, including infection, allergic reaction, severe blood loss, loss of function of a limb or organ, paralysis, disfiguring scars, brain damage, cardiac arrest, or death. Additional risks of anesthetic procedures, such as dental or nerve injury, headache, or backache, were also explained. The patient was informed about potential skin effects from prolonged x-ray exposure during fluoroscopy, including redness, temporary hair loss, and dry, itchy skin, which may occur after repeated or multiple procedures involving x-ray exposure to the same area. The patient consented to the participation of residents, fellows, and medical students in the procedure, as well as to the use of pictures or video recordings of the procedure for medical, scientific, or educational purposes, with the assurance that their identity would not be published. The patient also consented to the disposal of any tissue, body parts, or organs removed during the procedure and to the testing of tissue for advancing medical research, with the understanding that no costs or financial awards would be provided, nor would results be shared. The patient consented to the transfusion of blood or blood components and confirmed receipt of blood transfusion education, including an explanation of risks, benefits, and alternatives. The consent form was signed by the patient’s wife as an authorized representative at 13:00 on 03/29/2023, with a witness signature also documented.

events.description_full: The patient, Frank Ward, was evaluated during a physical therapy session. The patient was supine in bed upon entry, with no verbalizations and on trach to vent. Precautions included MCA CVA with evolution, s/p TNK and thrombectomy, increased midline shift with left craniectomy, helmet, trach to vent, PEG tube, and new dialysis. The patient did not rate pain. Passive range of motion (PROM) was performed on bilateral lower extremities (B LEs) for 10 repetitions in all planes to patient tolerance. PROM was within functional limits (WFL) with good tolerance. The patient was left in bed with all needs in reach and all lines and tubes in place. The assessment noted decreased functional ability, balance, activity tolerance, sensation, and lower extremity strength, as well as generalized weakness, fall risk, impaired transfers, decreased safe judgment, and left-side flaccidity with spontaneous movement on the right side but not to command. The patient required 24/7 care. The plan included gait training, endurance exercises, transfer training, bed mobility, therapeutic exercises, strengthening, balance training, neuro re-education, patient/family education, equipment evaluation, stair training, range of motion exercises, and wheelchair mobility. Discharge recommendations included continued post-acute therapy and transfer to a long-term acute care (LTAC) facility.

events.description_full: The patient, Frank Ward, was evaluated during an occupational therapy session. The patient was received in bed and was agreeable to therapy. No complaints of pain were noted. The patient’s active problem list included CVA (cerebral vascular accident), hypertensive emergency, type 2 diabetes mellitus in obesity, s/p craniotomy, presence of IVC filter, acute respiratory failure with hypoxia, structural encephalopathy, dysphagia, staphylococcal pneumonia, pneumonia of the right lower lobe due to Pseudomonas species, acute kidney injury, and persistent proteinuria. During the session, the patient exhibited a Modified Rankin Score of 5. The left upper extremity (L UE) was tremulous upon first interaction/stimuli, with uncertainty if this was due to startle or another response. The patient had received a blood transfusion overnight and there were plans for a possible thoracentesis. The session focused on bilateral upper extremity (BUE) range of motion (ROM) at the bed level to improve strength, activity tolerance, and musculoskeletal integrity. Passive range of motion (PROM) was performed on the left upper extremity (L UE), and active-assisted range of motion (AAROM) was performed on the right upper extremity (R UE) with resistance in shoulder flexion greater than 90 degrees. The patient was left in bed with all needs in reach. The assessment indicated that the patient would continue to benefit from skilled occupational therapy services to promote safety and independence in activities of daily living (ADLs) and functional mobility. Discharge recommendations included continued post-acute therapy and transfer to a long-term acute care (LTAC) facility.

events.title: Laboratory Results
events.notes: At 03:24, the patient underwent laboratory testing. Results showed sodium at 133.05 mmol/L (mildly decreased), potassium at 3.5 mmol/L (normal), chloride at 96.59 mmol/L (slightly decreased), and CO2 at 31 mmol/L (normal). Hemoglobin was 7.3 g/dL and hematocrit 23.1%, indicating anemia. Platelet count and WBC were within normal limits, while RBC was decreased at 2.57 x10^6/µL. Calcium was low at 7.4 mg/dL, and albumin was slightly decreased at 2.7 g/dL. These findings were consistent with ongoing anemia and mild hyponatremia. The clinical team monitored these values closely, particularly potassium and bicarbonate levels, due to risks associated with acute kidney injury.
events.description_full: The patient underwent laboratory testing at 03:24 on 2023-04-01. Sodium (Na) was measured at 133.05 mmol/L, which is mildly decreased. Potassium (K) was 3.5 mmol/L, within acceptable range. Chloride (Cl) was 96.59 mmol/L, slightly decreased. CO2 was 31 mmol/L, within normal limits. Blood urea nitrogen (BUN) was 19 mg/dL, showing improvement compared to prior values. Calcium was 7.4 mg/dL, uncorrected and low. Albumin was 2.7 g/dL, slightly decreased. Alkaline phosphatase (ALKPHOS) was not measured during this test. ALT and AST levels were not reported. Hemoglobin (HGB) was 7.3 g/dL, indicating anemia. Hematocrit (HCT) was 23.1%, also decreased. Platelet count (PLT) was 294 x10^3/µL, within normal range. White blood cell count (WBC) was 8.1 x10^3/µL, within normal limits. Red blood cell count (RBC) was 2.57 x10^6/µL, decreased. These results were consistent with ongoing anemia and mild hyponatremia. The patient’s potassium level was monitored closely due to risk of hyperkalemia secondary to acute kidney injury (AKI). Calcium and phosphorus levels were also monitored as part of mineral metabolism management. The patient remained at risk for metabolic acidosis, but bicarbonate levels were acceptable at 31 mmol/L. The clinical team continued to monitor these values closely and modulate treatment as needed.

events.description_full: The patient underwent a CT scan of the head without intravenous contrast at 5:30 AM to evaluate for intracranial hemorrhage following a craniotomy. Findings included a stable right craniotomy defect overlying the middle cerebral artery (MCA) territory large infarction, with stable foci of gyral and basal ganglia hyperattenuation suggestive of petechial hemorrhage. The study was interpreted by Dr. Richard Allen at 8:26 AM and electronically signed at 8:30 AM.

events.title: Nephrology Consultation
events.notes: At 23:11, Dr. Matthew Day conducted a nephrology consultation for acute kidney injury secondary to acute tubular necrosis. The patient was on hemodialysis with a Monday-Wednesday-Friday schedule. Recommendations included strict intake/output monitoring, daily weights, a renal diet, and fluid restriction to less than 1.5 liters per day. Labs showed potassium at 3.9 mmol/L, bicarbonate at 30 mmol/L, and hemoglobin at 8.1 g/dL. Erythropoietin therapy was initiated for anemia. Medications were reviewed and deemed appropriate for the patient’s renal function. The patient remained stable, with no immediate concerns noted.
events.description_full: Dr. Matthew Day provided a nephrology consultation for the patient at 23:11. The patient was noted to have acute kidney injury (AKI) secondary to acute tubular necrosis (ATN) and was currently on hemodialysis (HD) with a Monday-Wednesday-Friday schedule. Recommendations included strict intake/output monitoring, daily weights, a renal diet, and fluid restriction to less than 1.5 liters per day. The patient was at risk for hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis, and volume overload, and these conditions were being managed with dialysis and close monitoring. The patient's potassium level was 3.9, bicarbonate was 30, and sodium was 132.75 on the most recent labs. The patient was also noted to have anemia with a hemoglobin level of 8.1, and erythropoietin (EPO) therapy had been initiated. All medications were reviewed and deemed appropriate for the patient's renal function. The consultation concluded with a plan to continue monitoring and modulating treatment as needed. The patient remained stable, and no immediate concerns were noted.

events.title: Occupational Therapy Progress Note
events.notes: At 12:36, the claimant underwent an occupational therapy session with Tara Proto, OT, at Memorial Health. The patient, in a supine position, reported a sensation of falling but denied pain. Findings included a Modified Rankin Score of 5, poor sitting balance requiring maximum assistance, and left-sided inattention. Education was provided to the wife on addressing left-sided neglect and arm care for a large left shoulder subluxation. Sitting tolerance was less than 10 minutes due to dizziness, with a blood pressure of 183/96. The patient required maximum assistance for transfers and mobility. Recommendations included ongoing occupational therapy and intensive neurorehabilitation to maximize ADL performance and functional mobility.
events.description_full: The patient, Frank Ward, was met in a supine position in bed and was agreeable to therapy. The patient frequently reported a sensation of falling. General precautions included skin care, fall prevention, contact isolation, and supplemental oxygen. The patient has a history of MCA CVA with evolution, s/p TNK and thrombectomy, increased midline shift with left craniotomy, helmet use when up, trach collar at 35%, PEG tube, new dialysis, and MRSA. The patient did not report pain during the session. Objective evaluation revealed a Modified Rankin Score of 5. The patient was dependent for donning and doffing the helmet. Supine to sit transfer required maximum assistance of two people using a draw sheet. Sitting balance was poor, requiring maximum assistance, with short bouts of moderate assistance when the right hand was placed in the lap or used to hold onto the therapist. The patient demonstrated a tendency to push with the right upper extremity and had difficulty tracking to the left of midline. The wife was encouraged to continue addressing left-sided inattention. The patient was able to cross midline and rub the left affected side. Education on arm care was provided, noting a large subluxation in the left shoulder. Sitting tolerance was less than 10 minutes due to dizziness, with a blood pressure of 183/96. Functional transfers and mobility were limited, with sit-to-stand not tested and sit-to-supine requiring maximum assistance of two people. The patient was left in a side-lying position with the left upper extremity on two pillows, with the call light and essentials within reach. The patient was noted to be progressing towards goals, and ongoing occupational therapy services in acute care were recommended. The long-term goal was to maximize ADL performance and functional mobility to the highest possible level. The disposition recommendation was for the most intensive neurorehabilitation possible. The session lasted from 10:02 to 10:26, totaling 24 minutes.

events.title: Speech Therapy Progress Note
events.notes: At 13:42, the claimant was seen for dysphagia treatment in room 5604. A #6 cuffless Shiley tracheostomy tube was in place, and the claimant was on a trach collar. A speaking valve was placed, resulting in positive voicing with mildly weak vocal quality. Trials of ice chips, mildly thick liquid, and pureed consistencies showed slow mastication and delayed throat clearing, but no overt signs of aspiration. Recommendations included maintaining strict aspiration precautions, continuing speech therapy, and using the PEG tube for nutrition. The claimant's wife was educated on speaking valve placement and removal.
events.description_full: The claimant was seen in room 5604 for dysphagia treatment and was agreeable to speech therapy. A #6 cuffless Shiley tracheostomy tube was in place, and the claimant was on a trach collar. The claimant remains NPO except for ice chips and small teaspoons of puree sparingly for comfort only. During the session, the speech-language pathologist (SLP) placed a speaking valve, which resulted in positive voicing, though vocal quality was mildly weak. Minimal verbal responses to questions were noted, likely impacted by lethargy. Trials of ice chips, mildly thick liquid, and pureed consistencies were presented. The claimant demonstrated slow mastication of ice and delayed/immediate throat clearing with mildly thick liquid and pureed consistencies. No overt signs or symptoms of aspiration were observed during the trials, and the claimant maintained stable vitals throughout the session. Recommendations included continuing SLP therapy, maintaining strict aspiration precautions, and using the PEG tube as the primary source of nutrition and medication. The claimant's wife was educated on how to place and remove the speaking valve. The SLP will continue to monitor for PO tolerance and readiness for diet initiation as appropriate during the hospital stay.

events.description_full: On April 12, 2023, at 06:22, a blood transfusion procedure was documented for the patient, Frank Ward, at Memorial Health. The transfusion involved multiple units of blood products, including RBC AS-3 LR (Unit No: W204223596197, Product Code: E0685V00), RBC AS-1 LR (Unit No: W204223608336, Product Code: E0336V00), and WB CPD LR (Unit No: W200323450188, Product Code: E0033V00). All units were labeled as O Positive blood type, and compatibility testing was not performed, with the crossmatch interpretation noted as 'Uncrossmatched.' The transfusion was categorized as an emergency issue. The medical director of the laboratory, Dr. Steve Xie, oversaw the process, and verification procedures were completed by RN/MD/AA/CRNA staff, ensuring the blood container information matched the patient’s armband item by item in the patient’s presence. The patient verbalized understanding of signs and symptoms to report, including potential transfusion reactions such as temperature increase of 2°F or 1°C, systolic blood pressure decrease of 20-30 mmHg, hematuria, chills, abdominal/back pain, rash/itching, nausea/vomiting, and respiratory distress. No transfusion reaction was reported during this procedure. The transfusion checklist was followed, including immediate cessation of transfusion in case of reaction, comparison of patient armband and blood bag label, notification of the physician, documentation in Epic, and preparation for transfusion reaction workup if needed. The expiration dates for the blood products were noted as April 29, 2023, for RBC units and April 19, 2023, for WB CPD LR. The transfusion was completed without documented complications.

events.title: Physical Therapy Progress Note
events.notes: At 12:08, the patient was seen for physical therapy while supine in bed. Nursing cleared the patient for range of motion exercises. Precautions included MCA CVA with evolution, s/p TNK and thrombectomy, left craniectomy, helmet use when upright, trach collar, and PEG tube. Passive range of motion was performed on bilateral lower extremities to improve tissue extensibility and prevent contractures. The left lower extremity was positioned to prevent external rotation and abduction, while the ankle was aligned to facilitate dorsiflexion. Due to drowsiness from earlier medication, sitting edge-of-bed transfer and balance exercises were deferred. The patient remains in ICU with a Modified Rankin Score of 5. Recommendations included post-acute therapy focusing on mobility, strengthening, and neuro re-education.
events.description_full: The patient was cleared by nursing for range of motion exercises. Precautions included MCA CVA with evolution, s/p TNK and thrombectomy, increased midline shift with left craniectomy, helmet when up, trach collar, and PEG tube. The patient showed no appearance of pain during the session. The patient was supine in bed, and the RN reported that the patient had received medication earlier in the morning, causing increased drowsiness. Due to this drowsiness, sitting edge-of-bed transfer and seated balance exercises were deferred. The patient tolerated bilateral lower extremity passive range of motion (PROM) with total assistance to improve tissue extensibility, joint mobility, and prevent contractures. The left lower extremity was positioned into neutral hip alignment, and the patient's wife was educated on preventing frequent hip external rotation and abduction. The ankle was positioned to facilitate dorsiflexion to prevent prolonged plantar flexion and increased tightness in the ankle and Achilles tendon. Decreased active movement in the right lower extremity was noted, likely due to drowsiness from medication. The patient was scooted to the head of the bed in supine and repositioned into a chair position to improve physiological function and increase upright activity tolerance. The patient remains in ICU/critical care with a Modified Rankin Score of 5. The prognosis was noted as good with continued physical therapy post-acute discharge. Recommendations included gait training, transfer training, bed mobility, therapeutic exercise, therapeutic activity, strengthening, balance, neuro re-education, equipment evaluation/education, range of motion exercises, and wheelchair mobility. Discharge recommendations included continued post-acute therapy.

events.title: Occupational Therapy Progress Note
events.notes: At 12:49, the patient underwent occupational therapy. Nursing cleared the patient for treatment, noting drowsiness from earlier sedative use. Precautions included fall risk, skin precautions, right MCA CVA, left craniectomy with helmet use, trach collar, and PEG tube. Passive range of motion was performed on both upper extremities, revealing a large subluxation in the left shoulder and resistance in the right shoulder. The patient followed one simple command but demonstrated limited cognitive engagement. Total assistance was required for bed mobility and repositioning. Recommendations included post-acute therapy focusing on balance, ADLs, neuromuscular re-education, and equipment needs such as a Hoyer lift and specialty wheelchair.
events.description_full: The patient was cleared by the RN for treatment. The RN reported that the patient had received a sedative earlier, causing increased drowsiness. Precautions included fall risk, skin precautions, right MCA CVA with evolution, left craniectomy with helmet when up, trach collar, and PEG tube. The patient showed no signs of pain during the session. Cognitively, the patient demonstrated exceptions to within functional limits. The patient had eyes open upon the therapist's arrival but demonstrated upward gaze with no noted attention to the environment or tracking. The patient followed one simple command to squeeze with the right hand. Passive range of motion (PROM) was performed on the right upper extremity, with the patient actively resisting passive range to the right shoulder. Elbow and wrist movements were within functional limits. PROM was performed on the left upper extremity, where a large subluxation of the left shoulder was noted. PROM to the digits was performed with facilitation of digital flexion, and grimacing was noted with flexion. Wrist and elbow passive range of motion were within functional limits, with no pain response noted. The patient required total assistance from two individuals to scoot up and reposition in bed. The patient was placed in a chair position to promote increased physiological input. The patient was left in bed with the call light and essentials within reach. Progress was noted as slow due to medical status limitations. Recommendations included balance training, ADL/IADL training, functional mobility/transfers, functional activity tolerance, therapeutic activity, therapeutic exercise, range of motion exercises, patient/family education, energy conservation/pacing, neuromuscular re-education, sensation, cognition, vision/perception, coordination/fine motor skills, and upper extremity edema management. Discharge recommendations included continued post-acute therapy, 24-hour supervision, and equipment recommendations such as a Hoyer lift, hospital bed, and specialty wheelchair.

events.title: Physical Therapy Progress Note
events.notes: At 14:10, the patient was seen for physical therapy while in the ICU. The patient required total assistance for bed mobility and supine-to-sit transitions. Sitting balance training at the edge of the bed revealed significant posterior trunk lean, requiring maximum to total assistance. Verbal and tactile cues were provided for core activation, but the patient continued to push with the right upper extremity. Right lower extremity exercises were performed with six repetitions of knee extension and trace hip flexion. The Modified Rankin Score was 5, indicating severe functional impairment. The plan included continued physical therapy with interventions such as gait training, balance training, and neuro re-education.
events.description_full: The patient was supine in bed and agreeable to therapy. General precautions included fall and skin precautions, with specific considerations for right MCA CVA with evolution, left craniectomy requiring helmet use when upright, trach collar, and PEG tube. The patient reported pain in the right shoulder, and repositioning was performed for comfort after treatment. Bed mobility required total assistance from two individuals. The patient tolerated sitting at the edge of the bed (EOB) for seated upright activity tolerance and balance training, requiring maximum to total assistance for balance and trunk control. Verbal and tactile cues were provided for core activation to facilitate maintaining midline while seated, but the patient continued to exhibit posterior trunk lean and pushed with the right upper extremity, requiring cues to keep the arm in their lap. The patient followed commands for right lower extremity knee extension, completing six repetitions, and demonstrated trace hip flexion. Tactile cues and passive range of motion were used to facilitate cervical extension to neutral and rotation to the left and right. Transitioning from sitting to supine required total assistance from two individuals. The patient was repositioned in bed with total assistance, rolled to the left and right with tactile cues to facilitate reaching with the right upper extremity for increased bed mobility skills. The patient was left in bed with the call light and essentials within reach, and the bed alarm was activated. The Modified Rankin Score was documented as 5, indicating decreased high-level ADLs, functional ability, balance, activity tolerance, ambulation, gait, transfers, and ADL status. The prognosis was noted as good with continued physical therapy post-acute discharge. The patient remains in ICU/critical care. The plan included continued physical therapy interventions such as gait training, transfer training, bed mobility, therapeutic exercise, therapeutic activity, strengthening, balance training, neuro re-education, equipment evaluation and education, range of motion exercises, and wheelchair mobility.

events.title: Occupational Therapy Progress Note
events.notes: At 12:37, the patient was seen for occupational therapy. The patient expressed concerns about back pain and required total assistance for supine-to-sit transitions. Sitting balance was poor, with a strong left lean and pushing with the right upper extremity. The patient required maximum assistance for upper body dressing and was unable to engage in ADLs due to impaired balance and cognition. The Modified Rankin Score was 5. Equipment recommendations included a Hoyer lift, hospital bed, and specialty wheelchair.
events.description_full: The patient was seen for occupational therapy. Subjectively, the patient expressed concern, stating, 'Please don't break my back.' The patient reported back pain while seated at the edge of the bed (EOB). Precautions included right MCA CVA with evolution, left craniectomy with helmet when up, trach collar, and PEG tube. Cognitively, the patient was alert and responsive but demonstrated difficulty attending to directions, following one-step commands with repetition and increased time, and had decreased safety judgment and awareness of errors. The patient required cues to maintain midline in sitting and to attend to the left visual field. The patient perseverated on concerns about their back 'breaking' and exhibited a right gaze preference, making redirection difficult. Objectively, the patient required maximum assistance to raise their head from the bed surface to don a helmet and total assistance from two persons for supine-to-sit transitions with the head of the bed raised and bed rail support. Sitting balance was poor, requiring total assistance to maintain balance at the EOB. The patient exhibited a strong left lean and pushing with the right upper extremity, making it difficult to achieve midline. The patient was physically placed in right forearm weight-bearing to prevent heavy left lean and loss of balance. The patient was unable to engage in ADLs while seated at the EOB due to impaired sitting balance and cognition. Upper body dressing required maximum assistance in a semi-Fowler's position. The patient was left in bed with the call light and essentials within reach, and the bed alarm was activated. The assessment noted that the patient was progressing as expected and recommended continuing the occupational therapy plan of care. The treatment plan included interventions such as balance training, ADL/IADL training, functional mobility and transfers, therapeutic activity, therapeutic exercise, ROM, patient and family education, energy conservation, neuromuscular re-education, sensation, cognition, vision/perception, fine motor coordination, and upper extremity edema management. Discharge recommendations included continued post-acute therapy and equipment recommendations for a Hoyer lift, hospital bed, and specialty wheelchair.

events.description_full: The patient was seen for dysphagia treatment in room 2618. The patient was awake, alert, and confused but pleasant and agreeable to PO trials. The current diet was NPO with PEG tube feedings. The patient reported no pain. Respiratory status included a trach cuff. Behaviorally, the patient was alert, cooperative, and in a pleasant mood but required cueing. Vision was functional for self-feeding. The patient was positioned upright in bed. Baseline vocal quality was normal, and the patient demonstrated a strong volitional cough. Volitional swallow was within functional limits. Consistencies assessed included ice chips, which were presented via spoon. Oral and pharyngeal phases were within functional limits. Thin liquids were presented via straw, self-fed, and cup, with oral and pharyngeal phases also within functional limits. The assessment noted dysphagia and cognitive communication impairment, with progress being made toward goals. The plan included continuing speech therapy for dysphagia and communication. Recommendations included maintaining the NPO status with sips and chips as desired and tolerated.

events.notes: At 12:10, the patient was seen by speech-language pathologist Kristen Van Houten. The patient was tolerating a full liquid diet but had little appetite. The RN also reported that the patient had undergone physical therapy, a bath, and a bowel movement earlier in the morning. Pain medication was administered following these activities due to shoulder pain. Speech therapy was held for the time being. The patient's wife arrived at the bedside during the session, and the therapist discussed continuing the current diet plan. The wife aroused the patient for lunch, during which the patient consumed chicken noodle soup with good tolerance and interest in intake. The patient's tracheostomy tube was downsized earlier in the morning to a #4 Shiley cuffless, capped trach. No further therapy was conducted during this session.

events.title: Occupational Therapy Progress Note
events.notes: At 13:19, the patient participated in occupational therapy with Claire Graupmann, OT. The patient reported strong pain in the left upper extremity, which was addressed by repositioning and elevation. The patient required total assistance for bed mobility and sitting balance training due to a strong posterior and left lean. Cognitive assessment revealed alertness but decreased safety judgment and inattention to the left visual field. Gentle stretching was performed to prevent contractures. The therapist noted expected progress and recommended continuing therapy, including ADL training, balance exercises, and neuromuscular re-education. The patient was left in bed with safety measures in place.
events.description_full: The patient agreed to participate in occupational therapy. Precautions included right middle cerebral artery (R MCA) cerebrovascular accident (CVA) with evolution, left craniectomy requiring a helmet when upright, dense left hemiparesis with upper extremity subluxation, capped tracheostomy, and PEG tube. The patient reported strong pain in the left upper extremity, which was addressed by repositioning and elevating the limb at the end of the session. Cognitively, the patient was alert and responsive, following one-step commands with increased time. Safety judgment and awareness of errors were decreased, requiring assistance to identify and correct errors. The patient demonstrated inattention to the left visual field and required cues to attend to this area. During bed mobility, the patient required total assistance from two individuals to move with the head of the bed raised and bed rails in place. A helmet was donned while the patient was in a supine position, and the patient activated head lifting off the bed surface but required assistance to maintain head elevation. During sitting balance training at the edge of the bed, the patient required maximum assistance for static sitting balance due to a strong posterior and left lean. The patient demonstrated decreased trunk and cervical control, significant stiffness, and difficulty raising and rotating the neck. Gentle stretching was provided to the left hand to prevent extensor contractures. The patient was left in bed with the call light and essentials within reach, and the bed alarm was activated. The therapist noted that the patient was progressing as expected and recommended continuing the occupational therapy plan of care. The treatment plan included interventions such as balance training, ADL/IADL training, functional mobility and transfers, therapeutic activities, therapeutic exercises, ROM, patient and family education, energy conservation, neuromuscular re-education, sensation training, cognition, vision/perception, fine motor coordination, and upper extremity edema management. Post-acute therapy was recommended to maximize functional status, with the patient requiring comprehensive therapy involving two or more disciplines and tolerating at least three hours of therapy per day, five days per week.

events.title: Physical Therapy Progress Note
events.notes: At 14:25, the patient underwent physical therapy with Emily Robinson, PT. The patient, supine in bed, reported pain in the left hand, shoulder, and back. During supine-to-sit transfers, the patient required maximum assistance and tactile cues. Sitting balance training revealed a posterior trunk lean, progressing to brief periods of moderate assistance. Cervical range of motion stretching was performed to address right lateral flexion preference. The patient demonstrated motivation and active participation. The therapist assessed decreased functional ability, balance, and gait, with a fall risk. The prognosis was noted as good, and the patient was left in bed with safety measures in place.
events.description_full: The patient was supine in bed and agreeable to therapy. Precautions included right MCA CVA with evolution, left craniectomy with helmet required when upright, dense left hemiparesis with upper extremity subluxation, capped tracheostomy, and PEG tube. The patient reported pain in the left hand, shoulder, and back, and was repositioned for comfort after treatment. During the supine-to-sit transfer, the patient required maximum assistance from two people towards the right side, with cues provided for initiating and sequencing movements to assist with the right upper and lower extremities. Sitting balance training at the edge of the bed revealed an initial posterior trunk lean requiring maximum assistance, progressing to brief periods of moderate assistance with the right upper extremity using the bed rail for support. The patient tolerated propping onto the right elbow to increase weight-bearing and facilitate midline orientation. The patient demonstrated pushing up through the right upper extremity to midline with tactile cues and maximum assistance for maintaining midline orientation, as well as a left trunk and posterior lean. Cervical range of motion stretching was performed to promote rotation and lateral flexion due to a right lateral flexion preference. The patient followed commands and was noted to be motivated and actively participating in therapy. The patient was left in bed with the call light and essentials within reach, and the bed alarm was activated. The therapist assessed the patient as having decreased high-level ADLs, functional ability, balance, activity tolerance, ambulation, and gait, with a fall risk and impaired transfers. The prognosis was noted as good, and the patient was described as motivated with great participation during the session.

events.description_full: The patient was discharged from SAV 2 HV NEURO ICU on 05/03/2023 at 12:20. The discharge destination was an inpatient rehabilitation facility. The patient had been admitted on 02/17/2023 for acute ischemic stroke in the right MCA distribution, which was complicated by left-sided hemiparesis, dysphagia, hypertensive emergency, and structural encephalopathy. During the hospitalization, the patient underwent a decompressive hemicraniectomy and was treated for pneumonia, acute kidney injury, and acute respiratory failure with hypoxia. The patient also had a history of diabetes mellitus type 2 and the presence of an IVC filter. The discharge plan included continued rehabilitation for impaired mobility and activities of daily living. The attending physician, Dr. Spencer H Peterson, documented the discharge condition and plan for readmission to inpatient rehabilitation. The patient was noted to have persistent neurological deficits requiring ongoing therapy and monitoring.

events.title: Authorization for Disclosure of Protected Health Information
events.notes: On 2023-05-17, the claimant authorized the Neurosurgical & Spine Institute to disclose his protected health information (PHI), including medical and billing records, as well as sensitive information protected under federal and state laws. The authorization specified that PHI may be re-disclosed by recipients and is not subject to HIPAA protections. The claimant's wife, Rachael Ward, was listed as an authorized recipient, and the claimant signed the document on 2023-05-18.
events.description_full: The patient, Frank Ward Jr., authorized the Neurosurgical & Spine Institute, including its employees, agents, and contractors, to use or disclose his protected health information (PHI) as specified in the authorization. The PHI includes medical and billing information, as well as records protected under Federal Law (e.g., alcohol and drug abuse treatment information) and State Law (e.g., mental health diagnosis, treatment, or related communications, or information relating to diagnosis, testing, or treatment for AIDS, HIV, or other communicable diseases). The authorization specifies that all information in the medical record will be included unless specific items are submitted in writing. The authorization remains in effect until a written notice is provided to the Neurosurgical & Spine Institute. The patient understands that he may revoke the authorization by submitting a written request, but such revocation will not affect any use or disclosure made prior to the receipt of the revocation. The patient acknowledges that signing the authorization is not a condition for receiving medical treatment. The authorization also notes that PHI disclosed may be subject to re-disclosure by the recipient, who may not be subject to HIPAA Privacy Rule or other state or federal privacy laws. The patient will not receive compensation for the use or disclosure of his PHI, nor will the Neurosurgical & Spine Institute receive compensation for the disclosure. events.title: Treatment & Medication Agreement
events.notes: At 11:24, the claimant signed a treatment and medication agreement with Dr. Suh, outlining the risks of narcotic medications, including dependency, CNS depression, and respiratory arrest. The agreement prohibited obtaining medications from other providers and emphasized that narcotics are adjunctive therapy, not for long-term management. The claimant agreed not to share or replace lost medications and acknowledged the risks of combining narcotics with other substances.
events.description_full: The patient signed a treatment and medication agreement outlining the risks and guidelines associated with narcotic medications. The agreement emphasized the inherent risks of narcotic medications, including chemical dependency, addiction, CNS depression, hypotension, seizures, constipation, nausea, vomiting, dizziness, headache, confusion, respiratory arrest, somnolence, coma, and death. It also highlighted the dangers of combining narcotic medications with muscle relaxants, sleeping pills, anxiety medications, antihistamines, decongestants, or alcohol, which can cause cognitive impairment and delayed reaction time. The agreement stated that the patient would receive medications from one prescribing physician only and that obtaining medications from other physicians or ER physicians would result in discontinuation of prescriptions from the current provider. The patient agreed not to share, sell, or trade medications and acknowledged that lost or stolen medications would not be replaced. The agreement clarified that narcotic medications are adjunctive therapy and not intended for long-term management of symptoms under neurosurgical care. The patient signed the agreement, indicating understanding and acceptance of these terms.

events.title: CT Head without Contrast
events.notes: At 08:05, the patient underwent a CT scan of the head without contrast as part of pre-operative evaluation. Sagittal and coronal reformats were obtained. Findings included stable postsurgical changes of a right frontoparietotemporal craniectomy, encephalomalacia within the right MCA territory, and mildly decreased transcranial herniation. No acute intracranial hemorrhage, hydrocephalus, or midline shift was noted. Impression: No acute intracranial process. The report was electronically signed by Dr. Peter Britt at 08:29 and Dr. James Mitchell at 08:27.
events.description_full: The patient underwent a CT scan of the head without IV contrast as part of pre-operative evaluation. The imaging was performed from 08:05 to 08:12. Sagittal and coronal reformats were obtained. Findings included stable postsurgical changes of a right frontoparietotemporal craniectomy, a large region of encephalomalacia and gliosis within the right MCA territory, and mildly decreased transcranial herniation of brain parenchyma. No acute intracranial hemorrhage, no new regions of gray-white matter differentiation loss, no hydrocephalus, and no midline shift were noted. Stable ex vacuo dilation of the right lateral ventricle secondary to prior MCA infarction was observed. The density of the dural venous sinuses was normal. No new calvarial or skull base abnormality was identified. Additional findings included a right maxillary sinus mucocele versus retention cyst and chronic opacification of the mastoid air cells bilaterally. The visualized orbits were unremarkable. Impression: No acute intracranial process. Large region of right MCA territory encephalomalacia with mildly decreased transcranial herniation of brain parenchyma. The report was electronically signed by Peter Britt, MD at 08:29 and James Mitchell, MD at 08:27.

events.title: Physical Therapy Progress Note
events.notes: At 13:29, the claimant was evaluated by Kendra Smith, PT, following a recent bone flap replacement and history of CVA with left-sided deficits. The patient required maximum assistance for supine-to-sit transitions and moderate assistance for sitting balance. Exercises focused on trunk control, sitting balance, and cervical stretching to address right-sided tightness. Pain was noted in the left hip during range of motion exercises. The assessment identified generalized weakness, impaired transfers, and high fall risk requiring 24/7 assistance. Recommendations included post-acute therapy involving multiple disciplines for three hours per day, five days per week.
events.description_full: The patient, Frank Ward, was evaluated by Kendra Smith, PT, on June 26, 2023, at 13:29. The patient agreed to treatment and was noted to have precautions due to a recent bone flap replacement during this hospital stay, a history of CVA with hemorrhagic conversion, and left-sided deficits. The patient complained of left hip pain during range of motion exercises and was repositioned for comfort. Upon entering the room, the patient was supine in bed. Supine-to-sit transitions required maximum assistance, and the patient sat on the edge of the bed with moderate assistance and maximum cues to reduce pushing to the left side and leaning to the left. Right upper extremity extension was facilitated to improve upright posture during sitting. The patient withdrew from pain in the left lower extremity during dynamic reaching exercises aimed at improving trunk control and sitting balance. Cervical stretching was performed to address right-sided tightness, as the patient favored right lateral flexion. Sit-to-supine transitions required maximum assistance. The patient was positioned on the left side for pressure relief and right cervical stretching, with cues provided for midline awareness. The patient was left in bed with needs within reach, the bed alarm activated, and lines in place. The assessment noted decreased functional ability, balance, activity tolerance, and lower extremity strength, as well as impaired transfers, decreased safe judgment, and a decline in ambulation. The patient was identified as having generalized weakness and a high fall risk, requiring 24/7 assistance. The treatment plan included gait training, transfer training, bed mobility, therapeutic exercise, therapeutic activity, strengthening, balance training, neuro re-education, equipment evaluation and education, range of motion exercises, wheelchair mobility, endurance training, patient and family education, and stair training. Discharge recommendations included post-acute therapy to maximize functional status, requiring comprehensive therapy in two or more disciplines for at least three hours per day, five days per week. The evaluation time was calculated as 23 minutes, from 10:12 to 10:35. The note was electronically signed by Kendra Smith, PT, at 13:35.

events.title: Occupational Therapy Treatment
events.notes: At 16:00, the claimant was evaluated by Kara Scott, OT, following a recent cranioplasty and history of CVA with left-sided deficits. The patient required maximum assistance for supine-to-sit transitions and demonstrated slowed responses during therapy. Sitting balance was improved with weight-bearing on the left upper extremity for sensory input and neuro re-education. Pain was noted with lower extremity movement. The assessment identified impaired functional mobility and safety concerns. Recommendations included continued skilled OT services to promote independence in activities of daily living and functional mobility.
events.description_full: The patient, Frank Ward, was evaluated by Kara Scott, OT, on June 26, 2023, at 16:00. The patient presented with an active problem list including CVA, hypertensive emergency, type 2 diabetes mellitus in obesity, status post craniotomy, acute respiratory failure with hypoxia, structural encephalopathy, dysphagia, staphylococcal pneumonia, pneumonia of the right lower lobe due to Pseudomonas species, acute kidney injury, persistent proteinuria, acute blood loss anemia, acute ischemic right MCA stroke, cardiac arrest, and acquired skull defect. The patient was four days post-op from a cranioplasty with autologous bone flap replacement. Precautions included fall risk and considerations related to the bone flap replacement and history of CVA with hemorrhagic conversion and left-sided deficits. The patient was received in bed and agreeable to therapy, though they made slowed responses and required increased time to engage with the therapist. The patient complained of pain with lower extremity and hip movement. During the evaluation, the patient demonstrated a Modified Rankin Score of 4. Supine scooting to the head of the bed for improved positioning required total assistance. Supine-to-sit transitions to the left side of the bed required maximum assistance, though the patient was able to initiate upper body movement and assist with the right side. Therapy focused on sitting balance, upright tolerance, body awareness, and spatial positioning. The patient required moderate to minimal assistance for sitting balance at the edge of the bed, with cues to avoid pushing with the right upper extremity. The right upper extremity was extended on the bed rail for support and to reduce pushing, while weight-bearing through the left upper extremity was encouraged to increase sensory input and facilitate neuro re-education. Sit-to-supine transitions required maximum assistance. The patient was left in bed with needs within reach. The assessment concluded that the patient would continue to benefit from skilled occupational therapy services to promote safety and independence in activities of daily living and functional mobility. The note was electronically signed by Kara Scott, OT, at 16:04.

events.title: CT Head Without IV Contrast
events.notes: The claimant underwent a CT head without IV contrast on 07/04/2023 as part of a stroke protocol. The imaging revealed hypodensity in the right MCA territory, consistent with a maturing infarct. Postoperative fluid and air were noted under the craniotomy, measuring up to 1.6 cm. Additional findings included soft tissue swelling and air foci along the right convexity scalp, as well as opacification of the right mastoid air cells. Follow-up imaging was recommended to monitor resolution of the right convexity fluid.
events.description_full: The patient underwent a CT head without IV contrast on 2023-07-04 as part of a stroke protocol. The clinical indication for the imaging was 'STROKEP - Stroke Protocol.' The imaging was performed using unenhanced axial images obtained from the skull base to the vertex. Dose-optimizing techniques were utilized, including automated exposure control, adjustment of mA and/or kV according to patient size, and/or use of iterative reconstruction technique. Comparison was made to a prior head CT without contrast dated 2023-05-22. Findings included no mass effect or midline shift, with mild ex vacuo dilatation of portions of the right lateral ventricle. Hypodensity was noted throughout the right MCA territory, consistent with a maturing infarct. Postoperative fluid and air were observed underlying the craniotomy, measuring up to 1.6 cm on coronal images. Scattered air foci were present within the left ventricle. Additionally, soft tissue swelling, fluid, and air foci were noted along the right convexity scalp. Opacification of the right mastoid air cells and right middle ear was also documented. The impression included expected changes related to a recent autologous right hemispheric cranioplasty with postoperative fluid underlying the craniotomy, soft tissue swelling, and fluid overlying the right convexity. Follow-up examination was recommended to document resolution of the right convexity fluid. The findings were consistent with a maturing right MCA territory infarct. The report was electronically signed by Dr. James R. Mason on 2023-07-06 at 16:51.

events.title: Consent for Thoracentesis and Bronchoscopy
events.notes: At 13:00, the patient, Frank Ward, consented to two procedures: thoracentesis and bronchoscopy. The consent forms outlined the risks, benefits, and alternatives, including potential complications such as infection, severe blood loss, and anesthetic risks. The patient agreed to the administration of anesthetics and the participation of medical trainees. Additional consents included the use of fluoroscopy, tissue disposal for research, and blood transfusion if necessary. The forms were signed by the patient or their authorized representative and witnessed by staff. No guarantees regarding outcomes were provided.
events.description_full: The patient, Frank Ward, consented to a proposed procedure, which was documented as 'Thora renteris.' The consent form outlined the patient's agreement to allow Dr. Casey H Morris or a designee to perform the procedure, as well as any additional operations or procedures deemed necessary based on findings during the operation. The patient acknowledged that no guarantee or assurance was made regarding the outcomes of the procedure. The risks, benefits, and alternative methods of treatment were explained to the patient, who confirmed understanding of the explanation provided. The patient consented to the administration of anesthetics and/or sedation, which may be administered and monitored by an anesthesiologist, a certified registered nurse anesthetist, or an anesthesia assistant under the medical direction of an anesthesiologist. Risks associated with the procedure were detailed, including infection, allergic reaction, severe blood loss, loss of function of a limb or organ, paralysis, disfiguring scars, brain damage, cardiac arrest, or death. Risks specific to anesthetic procedures, such as dental or nerve injury, headache, or backache, were also noted. The patient was informed about potential skin effects from prolonged exposure to x-rays during fluoroscopy, including redness, temporary hair loss, and dry, itchy skin, which may occur after repeated or multiple procedures involving x-ray exposure to the same area. The patient consented to the participation of residents, fellows, and medical students in the procedure, as well as the use of pictures or video recordings of the procedure for medical, scientific, or educational purposes, with the assurance that their identity would not be published. The patient also consented to the disposal of any tissue, body parts, or organs removed during the procedure and the testing of tissue for advancing medical research, with the understanding that there would be no costs or financial awards for this testing and no results would be provided to the patient. The patient was given the option to consent to or refuse the transfusion of blood or blood components, with the risks, benefits, and alternatives explained. The patient signed the consent form, indicating they had read and understood the document, had the opportunity to ask questions, and gave permission for the items outlined, except for any items they specifically declined, dated, timed, and signed.

events.title: Establish Care Visit
events.notes: At 15:00, the patient presented to establish care with Dr. Mohammad M. Hussain. The patient has a history of left-sided hemiparesis due to a prior stroke, chronic pain, and type 2 diabetes requiring insulin. Medications were reviewed, and a pain management plan was discussed. The patient’s BMI was 28.37 kg/m2. Referrals were made to neurology, speech therapy, and pain management. Naloxone and hydrocodone-acetaminophen were prescribed for pain management and overdose prevention. The visit lasted approximately 60 minutes, and follow-up was scheduled in six weeks.
events.description_full: The patient presented to University Health Internal Medicine for an office visit to establish care. The patient has a history of left-sided hemiparesis as a late effect of a cerebral infarction, deep vein thrombosis (DVT) of the calf muscle vein (unspecified chronicity and laterality), type 2 diabetes mellitus with other specified complications requiring long-term insulin use, hyperlipidemia, other chronic pain, and chronic continuous use of opioids. The patient is paralyzed, as noted in the visit documentation. The patient was checked in at 2:50 PM and the consultation began at 3:00 PM, lasting approximately 60 minutes. During the visit, the provider reviewed the patient's medical history and current medications, which include Naloxone (NARCAN) 4 MG/0.1ML Liquid, amLODIPine (NORVASC) 10 MG Tab, ALPRAZolam (XANAX) 0.5 MG Tab, ELIQUIS 5 MG Tab, ASPIRIN LOW DOSE 81 MG EC tablet, atorvastatin (LIPITOR) 80 MG tablet, chlorthalidone (HYGROTON) 50 MG Tab, cloNIDine (CATAPRES) 0.3 MG/24HR PATCH WEEKLY patch, Continuous Blood Glucose Sensor (FREESTYLE LIBRE 14 DAY SENSOR), JARDIANCE 10 MG Tab, FEROSUL 325 (65 Fe) MG tablet, FLUoxetine (PROZAC) 20 MG Cap, hydrALAZINE (APRESOLINE) 100 MG tablet, Insulin Aspart FlexPen 100 UNIT/ML Solution Pen-injector, LANTUS SOLOSTAR 100 UNIT/ML Solution Pen-injector, levetiracetam (KEPPRA) 1000 MG tablet, losartan (COZAAR) 100 MG Tab, methocarbamol (ROBAXIN) 750 MG Tab, minoxidil (LONITEN) 2.5 MG Tab, ondansetron (ZOFRAN ODT) 4 MG TABLET DISPERSIBLE, oxyCODONE immediate release (ROXICODONE) 10 MG immediate release tablet, pantoprazole (PROTONIX) 40 MG Tablet Delayed Response, traZODone (DESYREL) 50 MG Tab, and HYDROcodone-acetaminophen (NORCO) 5-325 MG Tab. The patient’s BMI was calculated as 28.37 kg/m2, and body surface area was noted as 2.33 m2. The provider documented the patient’s paralysis and agreed to a pain management plan. Insurance verification was completed, and the visit was scheduled by the patient’s wife, Rachael. The patient was checked out at 4:24 PM.

events.title: Discharge Information
events.notes: The claimant was provided with detailed discharge instructions, including guidance on medication use, monitoring for side effects, and precautions to avoid injury. Instructions emphasized the importance of consulting a healthcare provider before stopping medications and reporting any concerning symptoms such as breathing difficulties, chest pain, or sudden weakness. Additionally, the claimant received information on suicide prevention, including warning signs and resources such as the national suicide prevention hotline (988) and the Georgia crisis access line. The document highlighted the availability of confidential support 24/7.
events.description_full: The patient was provided with detailed discharge instructions regarding the use of their prescribed medication. The instructions emphasized the importance of regular monitoring by a healthcare professional while taking the medication. The patient was advised to notify their doctor or seek emergency treatment if they experienced symptoms such as breathing problems, changes in vision, chest pain, severe or sudden headache, pain or swelling in the leg, trouble speaking, or sudden numbness or weakness in the face, arm, or leg, as these could indicate worsening of their condition. The patient was instructed not to stop taking the medication without consulting their doctor and to ensure their prescription was refilled before running out. Additional precautions included avoiding activities that might cause injury due to the risk of unseen bleeding, taking care when using sharp tools, and using an electric razor and soft toothbrush to minimize the risk of cuts or bleeding. The patient was also instructed to report any injuries, bruising, or red spots on the skin to their healthcare provider. The document noted that this was a summary and encouraged the patient to consult their doctor, pharmacist, or healthcare provider for any questions about the medication.

events.title: CT Head Without Contrast
events.notes: On October 5, 2023, the patient underwent a CT head without contrast at HCA Florida Memorial Hospital as part of the stroke protocol. Axial images were obtained from the skull base to the vertex. Findings included hypodensity in the right MCA territory consistent with a maturing infarct, mild ex vacuo dilatation of the right lateral ventricle, and postoperative changes from a recent cranioplasty. No mass effect or midline shift was observed. Follow-up imaging was recommended to monitor resolution of fluid accumulation.
events.description_full: The patient underwent a CT head without IV contrast as part of the stroke protocol. Axial images were obtained from the skull base to the vertex using dose-optimizing techniques such as automated exposure control, adjustment of mA and/or kV according to patient size, and iterative reconstruction technique. Comparison was made to a prior head CT dated May 22, 2023. Findings included hypodensity throughout the right MCA territory consistent with a maturing infarct. Mild ex vacuo dilatation of portions of the right lateral ventricle was noted without mass effect or midline shift. Postoperative fluid and air underlying the craniotomy measured up to 1.6 cm on coronal images, with scattered air foci within the left ventricle. Soft tissue swelling, fluid, and air foci were observed along the right convexity scalp, along with opacification of the right mastoid air cells and right middle ear. Impression included expected changes related to recent autologous right hemispheric cranioplasty, postoperative fluid underlying the craniotomy, and soft tissue swelling overlying the right convexity. Follow-up imaging was recommended to document resolution of the right convexity fluid. The report was electronically signed by James R. Mason, DO on July 6, 2023, at 10:28.

events.title: Right Cranioplasty
events.notes: On October 5, 2023, the patient underwent a right frontotemporoparietal cranioplasty at Memorial Health University Medical Center, performed by Dr. Daniel Suh. This procedure involved replacing the patient’s own bone flap, initially removed during a decompressive hemicraniectomy in February 2023. The surgery was completed without complications, and postoperative imaging confirmed stable findings. The patient was discharged in stable condition on June 28, 2023, following recovery and resumption of anticoagulation therapy.
events.description_full: The patient underwent a right cranioplasty frontotemporoparietal with replacement of his own bone flap on June 22, 2023, following a large right MCA territory infarct sustained in February 2023. The infarct had led to cerebral edema, necessitating a right decompressive hemicraniectomy with removal of the bone flap on February 27, 2023. The patient had a complicated and protracted recovery postoperatively, as documented in prior hospital records. By June 2023, he had recovered sufficiently for replacement of the cranial flap. The surgery was performed without complications, and the patient tolerated the procedure well. Postoperative imaging on June 23, 2023, revealed postsurgical changes of the right frontoparietal bone flap reconstruction, a large region of extra-axial pneumocephalus, and a small amount of blood products along the right frontoparietal convexity. Pneumocephalus tracked into the area of encephalomalacia within the right frontal lobe and into the frontal horns and right temporal horn of the lateral ventricles. No significant midline shift was observed. Subsequent imaging on June 24 and June 27 showed stable findings, even after resuming anticoagulation therapy. The patient was discharged in stable condition on June 28, 2023.
