events.title: Physician Progress Notes Attestation
events.notes: At 08:15, Dr. Nikita Lopez signed the attestation for progress notes authored by Dr. Mohammad M. Hussain on 10/09/2023. The attestation confirmed review of the claimant's medical history, physical examination, laboratory results, and assessment. Diagnoses included pressure injury of the foot, urinary and fecal incontinence, left hemiparesis, influenza, hypokalemia, and vaccine administration. The claimant reported no new complaints but experienced vomiting during the visit, attributed to discomfort. Vital signs included blood pressure of 101/66, pulse of 52, temperature of 36.4°C, and oxygen saturation of 93%. Follow-up referrals for physical, occupational, and speech therapy were arranged.
events.description_full: Dr. Nikita Lopez signed the attestation for the progress notes authored by Dr. Mohammad M. Hussain on 10/09/2023. The attestation confirms that Dr. Lopez reviewed the patient's medical history, physical examination, laboratory results, and assessment, and discussed the findings and care plan with the resident physician. The patient was evaluated for follow-up on multiple diagnoses, including pressure injury of the foot (unstageable), urinary incontinence, fecal incontinence, left hemiparesis as a late effect of cerebral infarction, influenza, pneumococcal vaccine administration, and hypokalemia. The patient was noted to have no new complaints or concerns and received contact information for referrals to physical therapy, occupational therapy, and speech therapy. The patient reported not requiring medication refills at this time. During the visit, the patient experienced an episode of vomiting, attributed to discomfort from being in the clinic and wanting to leave. The patient appeared slightly improved compared to the previous visit, with increased activity and responsiveness. Vital signs included blood pressure of 101/66 (right arm, sitting position, small adult cuff), pulse of 52, temperature of 36.4°C (temporal), and oxygen saturation of 93%. The review of systems was largely negative except for neurological findings of focal weakness and generalized weakness. The patient requires specific medical supplies, including a condom catheter, catheter bags, foam pads for seating and ulcer prevention, and diapers (3xL). The patient also requires follow-up with physical therapy, occupational therapy, and speech therapy, which had not been previously arranged. The attestation confirms the accuracy and completeness of the documentation.

events.description_full: The patient underwent an Opioid Risk Tool (ORT) assessment. The demographic scoring noted the patient as male. The assessment evaluated family history of substance abuse, personal history of substance abuse, and psycho/social factors. The interpretation guide provided the following scoring criteria: a score of 0-3 indicates low risk of abuse, with a recommendation to perform urine drug screening (UDS) at least once per year; a score of 4-7 indicates moderate risk of abuse, with a recommendation to perform UDS 1-4 times per year; and a score of 8+ indicates high risk of abuse, with a recommendation to refer the patient to a specialist. The specific score for the patient was not documented in this entry.

events.title: Left Knee X-Ray
events.notes: At 13:30, the patient underwent imaging of the left knee due to atraumatic pain, swelling, and deformity. The study included lateral, merchant, notch view, and weightbearing standing AP views. Findings revealed no acute fracture, mild tricompartment degenerative changes, and a possible old fused osteochondral fragment in the lateral femoral condyle. No definite knee joint effusion was identified. The impression concluded no acute fracture and mild degenerative changes. The imaging results were electronically signed by Dr. Sharlene S. Su.
events.description_full: The patient underwent imaging of the left knee due to complaints of acute pain. The imaging was ordered by Dr. Sharlene S. Su during an office visit on 12/13/2023. The reason for the exam was documented as atraumatic pain, swelling, and deformity in the left knee. Specific instructions for the imaging included lateral, merchant, notch view, and weightbearing standing AP views. The patient required the use of a Hoyer lift for positioning. The imaging was completed with 5 views taken using digital radiography. The findings revealed no acute fracture of the left knee. There was a question of an old fused osteochondral fragment in the lateral femoral condyle. Mild tricompartment degenerative changes were noted, and no definite knee joint effusion was identified. The impression concluded no acute fracture and mild tricompartment degenerative changes of the left knee. The imaging results were electronically signed by Dr. Sharlene S. Su on 12/13/2023 at 13:30.

events.notes: The claimant underwent a chemodenervation procedure for spasticity and left-sided hemiparesis due to a prior cerebral infarction. The procedure involved ultrasound-guided needle placement for Xeomin (incobotulinumtoxinA) injections, with 100 units administered. The procedure was deemed urgent, and no complications or immediate outcomes were documented.
events.description_full: The patient was scheduled for chemodenervation of one extremity involving 1-4 muscles, with ultrasound guidance for needle placement. The procedure was indicated for spasticity (ICD-10 code R25.2) and hemiparesis of the left dominant side as a late effect of cerebral infarction (ICD-10 code 169.352). The patient also has a history of cerebrovascular accident (CVA) of unspecified mechanism (ICD-10 code I63.9). Authorization was requested for the use of Xeomin (incobotulinumtoxinA), with a total of 100 units ordered in a single vial (NDC code 00259-1610-01). The procedure was to be performed in the outpatient setting at the South Meadows Physiatry Clinic. The provider noted the use of injection modifier 76942 for ultrasound guidance. The patient was referred by Dr. Noel Blanco, D.O., and the procedure was deemed urgent. No additional details regarding the patient's response to prior treatments or specific physical examination findings were documented in this record.

events.title: Physician Progress Notes
events.notes: The claimant was evaluated via video visit for chronic pain and left-sided hemiparesis. Examination revealed tenderness in the left upper trapezius, levator scapula, and medial knee joint, with limited left shoulder range of motion. Neurological deficits included left-sided weakness graded 0/5 in multiple muscle groups. Pain management included Norco, oxycodone, and Robaxin. Trigger point injections were discussed, but left shoulder and knee injections were deferred due to lack of degenerative changes. A referral to the Pain Clinic was placed, and home physical therapy was recommended.
events.description_full: The patient was evaluated during a follow-up visit. Diagnoses included myalgia, acute pain of the right knee, acute pain of the left knee, chronic left shoulder pain, hemiparesis of the left dominant side as a late effect of cerebral infarction, cerebrovascular accident (unspecified mechanism), and osteoarthritis of the left acromioclavicular joint. The patient reported ongoing pain in the left shoulder and knees, as well as left-sided weakness. Examination findings included tenderness to palpation at the left upper trapezius, levator scapula, left adductor, and left medial knee joint. Limited passive range of motion of the left shoulder was noted, with pain reproduced during abduction, forward flexion, internal and external rotation. No significant tenderness was noted at the left AC or glenohumeral joint. Neurological examination revealed left-sided weakness with motor deficits graded as follows: Shoulder abduction (C5) 5/0, Elbow flexion (C5) 5/0, Wrist extension (C6) 5/0, Elbow extension (C7) 5/0, Finger flexion (C8) 5/0, Finger abduction (T1) 5/0, Hip flexion (L2) 4/0, Knee extension (L3) 4/0, Ankle dorsiflexion (L4) 4+/0, Toe extension (L5) 4+/0, Ankle plantarflexion (S1) 4+/0. Tenderness was noted bilaterally at the medial and lateral knee joint lines, worse on the right, with slightly decreased active range of motion in the right knee. No new imaging was deemed necessary at this time. The plan included continuation of home physical therapy and referral for home health physical therapy. Medications prescribed included Norco 5-325mg Q6H PRN and oxycodone 10mg BID PRN for pain management, with compliance to AB 474 noted. Robaxin was also continued for pain relief. Trigger point injections under ultrasound guidance with steroid were discussed, and the patient agreed to proceed with the procedure. Risks, benefits, and alternatives were explained, including potential complications such as damage to surrounding structures, infection, bleeding, worsening pain, and collapsed lung. The patient was advised that left shoulder or knee injections would likely not provide significant pain relief due to the lack of significant degenerative changes on imaging. Follow-up was scheduled for around 6/5 for trigger point injections, ensuring a three-month interval between steroid injections for safety reasons.

events.title: Screenings and Assessments
events.notes: At 11:19, the patient underwent multiple assessments conducted by Loraine R Child, Medical Assistant, at Renown Regional Medical Center. A PHQ-9 Depression Screening revealed no signs of depression, with a PHQ-2 score of 0. A Fall Risk Assessment determined no history of falls or injuries in the past year. An Opioid Risk Tool (ORT) assessment categorized the patient as low risk for opioid abuse, with recommendations for annual urine drug screening. No immediate concerns or interventions were identified during these evaluations.
events.description_full: The patient underwent a PHQ-9 Depression Screening conducted by Loraine R Child, Medical Assistant. The screening assessed the patient's mental health status over the past two weeks. The patient reported '0 - not at all' for both 'Little interest or pleasure in doing things' and 'Feeling down, depressed, or hopeless.' The PHQ-2 score was calculated as 0, indicating no signs of depression. No further questions were prompted based on the initial responses. The screening did not identify any mental health concerns requiring immediate intervention or follow-up. The provider documented the results accurately and attributed them to the patient’s current visit. The patient completed a Fall Risk Assessment under the supervision of Loraine R Child, Medical Assistant. The assessment determined that the patient had not experienced two or more falls in the past year nor any fall resulting in injury. The provider documented the results as 'No' for injury-related falls and 'Yes' for completion of the assessment. No additional safety concerns or interventions were noted during this evaluation. The assessment was completed as part of routine care and did not identify any immediate risks requiring further action. The patient underwent an Opioid Risk Tool (ORT) assessment conducted by Loraine R Child, Medical Assistant. The assessment evaluated the patient's risk for opioid abuse based on demographic and psychosocial factors. The patient was identified as male, with no family history of substance abuse, no personal history of substance abuse, and no psychosocial factors contributing to risk. The interpretation guide categorized the patient’s score as 0-3, indicating a low risk of abuse. Recommendations included conducting urine drug screening (UDS) at least once per year. The provider documented the results and provided guidance based on the assessment findings.

events.title: Follow-Up Visit
events.notes: At 11:40, the patient attended a follow-up visit with Dr. Sharlene S. Su at Renown Regional Medical Center. The patient reported acute pain in both knees, chronic left shoulder pain, and hemiparesis of the left dominant side due to a prior cerebrovascular accident. Diagnoses included myalgia, osteoarthritis of the left acromioclavicular joint, and late effects of cerebral infarction. Vital signs were recorded, and no abnormalities were noted. The provider emphasized ongoing management and scheduled follow-up appointments, including a virtual consultation on February 21, 2024.
events.description_full: The patient presented for a follow-up visit regarding acute pain in the right knee. Additional complaints included acute pain in the left knee, chronic left shoulder pain, and hemiparesis of the left dominant side as a late effect of a prior cerebrovascular accident (CVA). Diagnoses documented during the visit included myalgia, acute pain of the right knee, acute pain of the left knee, chronic left shoulder pain, hemiparesis of the left dominant side as a late effect of cerebral infarction, unspecified cerebrovascular accident, and osteoarthritis of the left acromioclavicular joint. The patient was checked in at 11:15 AM and checked out at 12:03 PM. The visit was completed with a copay of $0. The provider spent 30 minutes on evaluation and management, which was noted as significant and separately identifiable from other services provided on the same day. No additional procedures were documented during this visit.

events.title: Chemodenervation Procedure
events.notes: The claimant underwent a chemodenervation procedure performed by Dr. Noel Blanco to manage spasticity secondary to cerebrovascular accident (CVA). Botulinum toxin injections were administered into left upper extremity muscles, including the pectoralis, teres major, brachialis, and pronator muscles, totaling 150 units. Ultrasound guidance was used to ensure precision. Risks, benefits, and alternatives were discussed, and the claimant consented. The procedure was completed without complications, and follow-up was planned for further chemodenervation or acute issues.
events.description_full: The claimant underwent a chemodenervation procedure for management of spasticity secondary to cerebrovascular accident (CVA). The procedure targeted the left upper extremity muscles, including the left pectoralis, teres major, brachialis, flexor digitorum superficialis (FDS), flexor digitorum longus (FDL), and pronator quadratus (PQ). A total of 150 units of botulinum toxin were administered using 27-gauge needles and ultrasound guidance to avoid blood vessels. The claimant was maintained on anticoagulation therapy with Eliquis during the procedure due to the risks of discontinuation outweighing the procedural risks. Risks, benefits, and alternatives were discussed extensively with the claimant, including potential complications such as bleeding, hematoma, infection, worsening pain, weakness, flu-like symptoms, respiratory distress, dysphagia, and facial weakness. The claimant expressed understanding and consented to proceed. The procedure was performed without immediate complications. Follow-up was planned for chemodenervation or sooner if acute issues arise. The claimant was advised to continue current physical therapy and occupational therapy regimens, as well as home exercise programs. Exercise counseling and fall prevention strategies were also provided during the visit.

The results included the following: Sodium 142 mmol/L (normal range: 135-145 mmol/L), Potassium 3.8 mmol/L (normal range: 3.5-5.0 mmol/L), Chloride 104 mmol/L (normal range: 98-107 mmol/L), CO2 26 mmol/L (normal range: 22-29 mmol/L), Anion Gap 12.0 mmol/L (normal range: 8-16 mmol/L), Glucose 103 mg/dL (high, normal range: 70-99 mg/dL), BUN 23 mg/dL (high, normal range: 7-20 mg/dL), Creatinine 0.96 mg/dL (normal range: 0.6-1.2 mg/dL), Calcium 8.7 mg/dL (normal range: 8.5-10.5 mg/dL), AST (SGOT) 29 U/L (normal range: 10-40 U/L), ALT (SGPT) 45 U/L (normal range: 7-56 U/L), Total Bilirubin 0.6 mg/dL (normal range: 0.1-1.2 mg/dL), Albumin 3.5 g/dL (normal range: 3.4-5.4 g/dL), Total Protein 6.1 g/dL (normal range: 6.0-8.3 g/dL), Globulin 2.6 g/dL (normal range: 2.0-3.5 g/dL), A/G Ratio 1.3 (normal range: 1.1-2.5). Hematology results included: WBC 5.4 x10^3/uL (normal range: 4.0-11.0 x10^3/uL), RBC 4.62 x10^6/uL (low, normal range: 4.7-6.1 x10^6/uL), Hemoglobin 14.7 g/dL (normal range: 13.5-17.5 g/dL), Hematocrit 43.0% (normal range: 38.8-50.0%), MCV 93.1 fL (normal range: 80-100 fL), MCH 31.8 pg (normal range: 27-33 pg), MCHC 34.2 g/dL (normal range: 32-36 g/dL), MPV 11.0 fL (normal range: 7.4-10.4 fL), Neutrophils 39.40% (low, normal range: 40-70%), Lymphocytes 46.40% (high, normal range: 20-40%), Monocytes 9.20% (normal range: 2-10%), Eosinophils 4.40% (normal range: 0-6%), Basophils 0.40% (normal range: 0-1%). The procedure involves the injection of botulinum toxin for paralysis of nerve muscles in the arm or leg, targeting five or more muscles in the first extremity, with ultrasonic guidance for needle placement. The document also includes contact information for Hometown Health and instructions for accessing additional information or assistance. The claimant's diagnosis is spasticity (ICD-10 code R25.2), and the prescribed medication is Xeomin (Incobotulinumtoxin A) at a dosage of 200mg/ml, with administration instructions to inject 200 units every 12 weeks.

events.description_full: The patient participated in a telemedicine consultation with Dr. Noel Blanco, D.O., at Renown Med Group Physiatry. The reason for the visit was documented as spasticity, hemiparesis of the left dominant side as a late effect of a cerebral infarction, cerebrovascular accident (CVA) of unspecified mechanism, and wheelchair dependence. The level of service was documented as 'Office/Outpatient Established Moderate Medical Decision Making (MDM) 30 minutes.' The appointment was conducted as a virtual video visit, starting at 2:20 PM and lasting approximately 20 minutes. The patient was checked in at 2:28 PM by Julia M. Hatos, Medical Assistant, and checked out at 3:31 PM by Kaitlin N. Harris. The encounter included a Botox consultation as per the supervising provider's note. The patient’s immunization history was reviewed, including historical data on influenza and pneumococcal vaccines. The patient reported taking multiple medications, including atorvastatin, pantoprazole, hydrocodone-acetaminophen, oxycodone, and others. The patient’s medication regimen was reviewed, and renewals were noted for atorvastatin and pantoprazole, prescribed by Dr. Mohammad M. Hussain. The patient’s history of Guillain-Barre syndrome, egg allergies, and vaccine reactions was negative. The patient did not express concerns or hesitations regarding vaccines, and staff confirmed that resources were provided. The patient’s wheelchair dependence and spasticity were noted as ongoing issues related to the late effects of a cerebrovascular accident.

events.title: Physician Progress Notes
events.notes: Dr. Mohammad M Hussain evaluated the claimant for multiple ongoing conditions, including type 2 diabetes mellitus, left-sided hemiparesis post-stroke, and DVT. Referrals were made to ophthalmology for diabetic retinopathy screening, neurology for hemiparesis management, and cardiology for QT prolongation noted on EKG. Medications were adjusted, including discontinuation of ondansetron due to QTc prolongation and initiation of prochlorperazine. Additional prescriptions included Eliquis, alprazolam, atorvastatin, and hypertension medications. The claimant reported a perioral rash diagnosed as eczema, treated with triamcinolone cream. A controlled substance agreement was completed for chronic opioid use. Follow-up was recommended in three months.
events.description_full: The claimant presented with multiple ongoing medical conditions requiring management and follow-up. The claimant has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus with complications and long-term insulin use. A referral to ophthalmology was made for retinal screening for diabetic retinopathy. Additionally, the claimant's continuous glucose monitoring sensor (Freestyle Libre 14 Day Sensor) was refilled with instructions to use as directed every 14 days. The claimant also has left-sided hemiparesis as a late effect of a prior right MCA stroke, status post right hemicraniectomy. The claimant does not currently follow with neurology and was referred to a neurologist. A wheelchair order for a zero-gravity wheelchair was provided, as requested by the claimant's physical therapist, along with a bedside commode order. The claimant has a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and requested a refill of Eliquis, which was provided (5 mg, twice daily, 90 tablets, 3 refills). The claimant also has a history of anxiety and uses alprazolam as needed; a refill was provided (0.5 mg, 30 tablets, no refills). The claimant reported a new onset perioral rash with itching and scaliness, diagnosed as eczema. Physical examination revealed erythema without greasy appearance. A low-potency steroid cream (triamcinolone acetonide 0.1%) was prescribed for topical application twice daily (15 g, no refills). The claimant requested a refill of atorvastatin (Lipitor 80 mg, daily, 30 tablets, 2 refills) for hyperlipidemia. For hypertension, the claimant requested refills for amlodipine (10 mg, daily, 30 tablets, 5 refills), chlorthalidone (50 mg, daily, 30 tablets, 2 refills), and clonidine patches (0.3 mg/24hr, weekly, 4 patches, 3 refills). The claimant has a history of nausea and vomiting managed with ondansetron. An EKG performed during the visit revealed QTc prolongation (>500 ms). Ondansetron was discontinued, and the claimant was started on prochlorperazine (Compazine 5 mg, every 6 hours as needed, 30 tablets, 3 refills). A referral to cardiology was made for further evaluation of QT prolongation. The claimant also has a history of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and reported that omeprazole caused gastrointestinal upset compared to pantoprazole. A refill for pantoprazole (40 mg, daily, 30 tablets, 2 refills) was provided, and omeprazole was discontinued. The claimant has chronic opioid use for pain management associated with hemiparesis and physical therapy. A controlled substance treatment agreement was completed during the visit. The claimant uses Norco and oxycodone for pain management. Follow-up was recommended in approximately three months.

events.title: Trigger Point Injections
events.notes: At 12:24, the claimant underwent trigger point injections for myalgia (ICD-10-CM: M79.10) performed by Dr. Sharlene Su, MD, at Renown Regional Medical Center. The procedure utilized ultrasound guidance for precise needle placement and targeted areas of pain. Vitals prior to the procedure included blood pressure of 120/88 mmHg, pulse of 71 bpm, temperature of 97.7°F, and oxygen saturation of 96%. No sedation was used, and no complications were noted. Orders included diclofenac sodium gel and docusate sodium capsules. Follow-up was scheduled via video consultation in one month to assess progress.
events.description_full: The patient underwent trigger point injections in the area of pain under ultrasound guidance. The procedure was performed by Dr. Sharlene Su, MD, specializing in Interventional Pain and Spine Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation. The patient consented to all surgical, special diagnostic, or therapeutic procedures prior to the intervention. The diagnosis for the procedure was documented as myalgia (ICD-10-CM: M79.10). The patient’s vitals were recorded prior to the procedure: blood pressure 120/88 mmHg, pulse 71 bpm, temperature 97.7°F (36.5°C), and oxygen saturation 96%. The patient was positioned sitting, and the blood pressure was measured on the right arm using an adult-sized cuff. No adverse events or complications were noted during or immediately after the procedure. Follow-up was scheduled in one month via video consultation to assess progress and response to the injections. Orders placed during this encounter included diclofenac sodium (Voltaren) 1% gel and docusate sodium (Colace) 100 mg capsules. The provider reviewed and confirmed the supportive information documented in the Patient Health Questionnaire and Office Note with the patient and medical assistant.

events.notes: At 08:29, the claimant was prescribed hydrocodone-acetaminophen (Norco) 5-325 mg tablets for pain management related to hemiparesis of the left dominant side, a late effect of a cerebrovascular accident (CVA). The prescription, signed electronically by Dr. Mohammad M. Hussain, was to be taken as needed, one tablet every six hours for up to 30 days. The claimant was instructed to pick up the medication at Walgreens in Sparks, NV. The prescription was discontinued on 12/15/2023 by Dr. Nikita Lopez, with a reorder noted.
events.description_full: The claimant was prescribed HYDROcodone-acetaminophen (Norco) 5-325 MG tablets for pain management associated with a cerebrovascular accident (CVA). The medication was prescribed to be taken as needed, with instructions to take 1 tablet by mouth every 6 hours for up to 30 days. The claimant also uses oxycodone for breakthrough pain. The prescription was electronically signed by Dr. Mohammad M Hussain on 11/20/2023 at 15:32. The claimant was instructed to pick up the medication at Walgreens Drug Store in Sparks, NV, as they were going out of town. The medication was discontinued by Dr. Nikita Lopez on 12/15/2023 at 13:57, with a reorder noted. The claimant's diagnosis of hemiparesis of the left dominant side as a late effect of cerebral infarction (ICD-10-CM code I69.352) was documented as the indication for this medication.

events.description_full: The claimant underwent an Opioid Risk Tool (ORT) assessment during the visit. The assessment was completed by Dr. Mohammad M Hussain on 11/20/2023 at 14:17. events.title: Fluzone Quadrivalent vaccine administration
events.notes: At 08:29, the claimant received the Fluzone Quadrivalent influenza vaccine intramuscularly (0.5 mL). events.description_full: The patient received the Fluzone Quadrivalent influenza vaccine on 11/15/2024. The vaccine was administered intramuscularly with a dose of 0.5 mL. The scanned barcode associated with the vaccine was 01003492814235051724063010UT8040KA?21A08XMNK52KP6G5, and the manufacturer was Sanofi Pasteur. The vaccine's NDC code was 49281-423-50, and the VIS (Vaccine Information Statement) publish date was 8/6/2021. The documentation indicates that the vaccine was not patient-supplied, and the funding source was public non-VFC. The patient denied any history of Guillain-Barre syndrome, severe egg allergies, or prior severe reactions to this vaccine. The patient was not ill at the time of administration and had no concerns or hesitations regarding the vaccine. The staff addressed any potential concerns and provided resources as needed. The documentation on this immunization was noted as incomplete, but the administration details were recorded. The vaccine lot number was UT8040KA?21A08XMNK52KP6G5, and the expiration date was 6/30/2024.

events.title: Request for Production of Documents
events.notes: On March 26, 2025, Aisha Jones, representing MMPO Defense, submitted a formal request to Brooks Rehabilitation Hospital for the production of medical, billing, and diagnostic records related to patient Frank Ward Jr. The request included comprehensive billing records, diagnostic codes, and communication between physicians and the patient. Compliance with HIPAA regulations was emphasized, and prior approval was required for fees exceeding $101.00. This communication was part of the legal proceedings in the case of Frank Ward Jr. and Rachael Ward v. Savannah Health Services, LLC, et al.
events.description_full: On March 26, 2025, Ontellus submitted a formal request for the production of medical, billing, and diagnostic records for patient Frank Ward Jr. on behalf of MMPO Defense. The request was directed to Brooks Rehabilitation Hospital, located at 3599 University Blvd S., Jacksonville, FL 32216. The request specified the need for complete billing records from the first point of contact to the present, including charges, statements, explanation of benefits, payments, adjustments, write-offs, lien agreements, Letters of Protection, balances paid, balances due, CPT/diagnostic codes, and itemized billing charges. Additionally, the request included all billing emails between physicians and the patient, including secure messages. The letter emphasized compliance with HIPAA regulations and requested that records be sent to Ontellus at their Houston, Texas address. The letter also noted that if the fee for the records exceeded $101.00, prior approval from the attorney would be required. The request was signed by Aisha Jones, representing MMPO Defense, and included contact information for any questions or concerns. This communication is part of the legal proceedings in the case of Frank Ward Jr. and Rachael Ward v. Savannah Health Services, LLC, et al., under case number STCV24-03188.

events.title: Follow-up Request for Production of Documents
events.notes: On April 10, 2025, Brooks Rehabilitation Hospital received a follow-up communication from Aisha Jones, representing MMPO Defense, regarding the legal case of Frank Ward Jr. and Rachael Ward v. Savannah Health Services, LLC. The letter referenced the initial request dated March 26, 2025, and reiterated the need for comprehensive medical and billing records. Compliance with Georgia legal statutes was emphasized, and a timeline for objections was outlined. The communication confirmed that all attorneys in the Atlanta office are licensed to practice law in Georgia.
events.description_full: On April 10, 2025, Brooks Rehabilitation Hospital received a communication from Aisha Jones, representing MMPO Defense, regarding the legal case of Frank Ward Jr. and Rachael Ward v. Savannah Health Services, LLC and other defendants. The communication referenced a prior request submitted on March 26, 2025, for the production of medical, billing, and diagnostic records of Frank Ward Jr. The request specifically sought complete billing records from the first point of contact to the present, including charges, statements, explanation of benefits, payments, adjustments, write-offs, lien agreements, Letters of Protection between the facility and the patient's attorney, balances paid, balances due, CPT/diagnostic codes, and itemized billing charges. Additionally, the request included all billing emails between physicians and the patient, including secure messages. The communication emphasized compliance with legal statutes, including O.C.G.A. § 9-11-34(c)(2), O.C.G.A. § 24-8-803(6), O.C.G.A. § 24-9-902(11)(12), and O.C.G.A. § 24-8-826, and outlined the timeline for production, allowing twenty days for objections before compliance. The letter was signed by Aisha Jones, who confirmed that all attorneys in the Atlanta office are licensed to practice law in Georgia.

events.title: Chemodenervation Procedure
events.notes: At 17:37, Dr. Noel Blanco performed a chemodenervation procedure on the patient for spasticity in the left upper extremity. Using ultrasound guidance, 100 units of Xeomin were injected into targeted muscles, including the left pectoralis major and minor, teres major, and pronator teres. Risks, benefits, and alternatives were discussed, and the patient consented. Post-procedure, exercise counseling and fall prevention strategies were provided. Follow-up was scheduled for further chemodenervation or earlier if needed.
events.description_full: The patient underwent a chemodenervation procedure for spasticity affecting the left upper extremity. The procedure involved the injection of 100 units of Xeomin (incobotulinumtoxinA) distributed as follows: 25 units each into the left pectoralis major, left pectoralis minor, left teres major, and left pronator teres (PT). Ultrasound guidance was utilized to ensure accurate identification and targeting of the spastic muscles. The risks, benefits, and alternatives of the procedure were thoroughly discussed with the patient, including potential complications such as damage to surrounding structures, infection, bleeding, worsening or permanent pain, weakness, flu-like illness, fever, headache, myalgias, nausea, vomiting, respiratory distress, dysphagia, sialorrhea, and facial weakness. The patient expressed understanding and consented to proceed. Post-procedure, the patient was provided with exercise counseling and fall prevention strategies. Follow-up was scheduled for chemodenervation or sooner if acute issues arise. The patient was advised to contact the provider with any concerns prior to the next visit. Outside medical records, including imaging from Georgia Hospital, were requested with the patient’s signed consent. The note was electronically signed by Dr. Noel Blanco at 17:37.
